CHAPTER 1: CITY CHARTER

1.00   Form of government
   
2.00   Powers and duties

§ 1.00 FORM OF GOVERNMENT.
   The form of government of the City of Eldridge, Iowa is the Mayor-Council
form of government.
§ 2.00 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Council and Mayor and other City officers have such powers and shall
perform such duties as are authorized or required by State law and by this
Code, resolutions, rules, and regulations of the City of Eldridge, Iowa.
§ 2.01. The nomination process for the offices of Mayor and City Council shall
follow the procedure set forth in Iowa Code Chapter 45.1(8a). Elections for
these offices shall be governed by the provisions of Iowa Code Chapter 376.6
(2).
§ 3.00 NUMBER AND TERM OF COUNCIL.
   The Council consists of five council members elected at large, elected for
terms of four years.
§ 3.01 CHANGE IN REPRESENTATION.
   The form of Council representation may be changed by petition and election
as per the provisions of Iowa Code § 372.13(11). The City Council shall
schedule a special election to occur within sixty days of receipt of a valid
petition signed by ten percent (10%) of the eligible electors who voted in the
last regular city election. The petition must conform to the provisions of Iowa
Code § 362.4.
§ 3.02 EFFECTIVE DATE.
   If a majority of the persons voting at the special election approves the
changed plan, it becomes effective at the beginning of the term following the
next regular city election. If a majority does not approve the changed plan,
the Council shall not submit another proposal to change a plan to the voters
within the next two years.
§ 3.03 VOTING PRECINCTS.
   There shall be established two voting precincts in the city. The voting
precincts shall be described as follows.
Precinct 1
Beginning at the center line of the intersection of North Buttermilk Road and
West Donahue Street, then east along the center line of West Donahue Street to
the center line of the intersection of West Donahue Street and Dammann Drive,
then south and east along the center line of Dammann Drive until Dammann Drive
becomes West Davenport Street, then east along the center line of West
Davenport Street to the center line of the intersection of West Davenport
Street and North Fifth Street, then south along the center line of North Fifth
Street to the center line of the intersection of North Fifth Street and West
LeClaire Road, then east along the center line of West LeClaire Road to the
center line of the intersection of West LeClaire Road and South First Street,
then south along the center line of South First Street to the center line of
the intersection of South First Street and East Lincoln Road, then east along
the center line of East Lincoln Road to the east city limit boundary line, then
north along the east city limit boundary line to the north city limit boundary
line, the west along the north city limit boundary line approximately 2,648.25
feet west of the center line of North Buttermilk Road to a point on the west
city limit line, then south along the west city limit boundary line
approximately 1,330.93 feet to a point on the west city limit boundary line,
then east approximately 2,651.51 feet along the west city limit boundary line
to the center line of North Buttermilk Road, then south along the center line
of North Buttermilk Road to the point of beginning.
Precinct 2.
Beginning at the center line of the intersection of North Buttermilk Road and
West Donahue Street, then east along the center line of West Donahue Street to
the center line of the intersection of West Donahue Street and Dammann Drive,
then south and east along the center line of Dammann Drive until Dammann Drive
becomes West Davenport Street, then east along the center line of West
Davenport Street to the center line of the intersection of West Davenport
Street and North Fifth Street, then south along the center line of North Fifth
Street to the center line of the intersection of North Fifth Street and West
LeClaire Road, then east along the center line of West LeClaire Road to the
center line of the intersection of West LeClaire Road and South First Street,
then south along the center line of South First Street to the center line of
the intersection of South First Street and East Lincoln Road, then east along
the center line of East Lincoln Road to the east city limit boundary line, then
south along the east city limit boundary line to the south city limit boundary
line, then west along the south city limit boundary line to the west city limit
boundary line, then north along the west city limit boundary line to the point
of beginning.
(Ord. 2021-12, passed 12-20-2021)
§ 3.04 EFFECTIVE DATE.
   These precincts shall become effective January 15, 2022.
(Ord. 2021-12, passed 12-20-2021)
§ 4.00 TERM OF MAYOR.
   The Mayor is elected for a term of four years.
§ 5.00 COPIES ON FILE.
   The City Clerk shall keep an official copy of this Charter on file with the
official records of the City Clerk, shall immediately file a copy with the
Secretary of the State of Iowa, and shall keep copies of the Charter available
at the City Clerk’s office for public inspection.

§ 1.00 TITLE.
   The name of this code shall be the “Eldridge City Code” and all laws and
amendments which become effective after adoption of this code shall be compiled
as supplements to this code and, upon adoption, shall become part of this code.
§ 2.00 REPEALER.
   All prior ordinances or parts thereof are hereby repealed.
§ 3.00 PENALTIES.
§ 3.01 MISDEMEANOR.
   Unless otherwise provided therein, any person, firm or corporation violating
any of the provisions of this code shall have, upon conviction, committed a
simple misdemeanor, as specified in Iowa Code § 701.8, and shall be subject to
imprisonment for up to 30 days or to a fine of up to $500.
   (A)   Each act of violation and every day upon which violation occurs
constitutes a separate offense.
   (B)   The failure of any officer or employee of the city to perform any
official duty imposed by any of the provisions of this code shall not subject
such officer or employee to any penalties imposed herein for violation unless a
penalty is specifically imposed.
§ 3.02 MUNICIPAL INFRACTION.
   A violation of this code of ordinances, or any ordinance or code herein
adopted by reference, or the omission or failure to perform any act or duty
required by the same, with the exception of those provisions specifically
provided under state law as a felony, an aggravated misdemeanor or a serious
misdemeanor, or if the violation is a simple misdemeanor under Iowa Code
Chapters 690 through 732, is a municipal infraction punishable by civil penalty
as provided herein.
   (A)   Environmental violation.
      (1)   A municipal infraction which is a violation of Iowa Code Chapter
455B or of a standard established by the city in consultation with the State
Department of Natural Resources, or both, is classified as an environmental
violation. However, the provisions of this subsection regarding environmental
violations shall not be applicable until the city has offered to participate in
informal negotiations regarding the violation.
      (2)   The discharge of airborne residue from grain, created by the
handling, drying or storing of grain by a person not engaged in the industrial
production or manufacturing of grain products or by a person engaged in such
industrial production or manufacturing in such discharge occurs from September
15 to January 15, shall not be deemed to be a municipal infraction.
   (B)   Penalties. A municipal infraction is punishable by the following civil
penalties:
      (1)   Standard civil penalties.
         (a)   1.   First offense: $750;
            2.   Second offense of the same chapter of city code by the same
defendant: $1,000; and
            3.   Subsequent offenses: $1,000.
         (b)   Each day that a violation occurs or is permitted to exist
constitutes a repeat offense.
      (2)   Special civil penalties.
         (a)   A municipal infraction arising from non-compliance, pretreatment
standard or requirement referred to in 40 C.F.R. § 403.8, by an industrial use,
is punishable by a penalty, but not more than $1,000 for each violation exists
or continues.
         (b)   1.   A municipal infraction classified above as an environmental
violation is punishable by a penalty of not more than $1,000 for each
occurrence. However, such an environmental violation is not subject to such
penalty if all of the following conditions are satisfied:
               a.   The violation results solely from conducting an initial
startup, cleaning, repairing, performing scheduled maintenance, testing or
conducting a shutdown of either equipment causing the violation or the
equipment designed to reduce or eliminate the violation;
               b.   The city is notified of the violation within 24 hours from
the time that the violation begins; and
               c.   The violation does not continue in existence for more than
eight hours.
            2.   Each day that a violation exists or is permitted to exist
constitutes a repeat offense.
   (C)   Civil citations.
      (1)   Any officer authorized by the city to enforce this code of
ordinances may issue a civil citation to a person who commits a municipal
infraction. The citation will, first, be served by personal service as provided
in Rule of Civil Procedure 1.305 or, second, by certified mail addressed to the
defendant at defendant’s last known mailing address, return receipt requested
or, third, by publication in the manner as provided in Rule of Civil Procedure
1.310 and subject to the conditions of Rule of Civil Procedure 1.301 through
1.311.
      (2)   (a)   A copy of the citation shall be retained by the issuing
officer and one copy shall be sent to the Clerk of the District Court.
         (b)   The citation shall serve as notification that a civil offense
has been committed and shall contain the following information:
            1.   The name and address of the defendant;
            2.   The name or description of the infraction attested to by the
officer issuing the citation;
            3.   The location and time of the infraction;
            4.   The amount of civil penalty to be assessed or the alternative
relief sought, or both;
            5.   The manner, location and time in which the penalty must be
paid;
            6.   The time and place of court appearance; and
            7.   The penalty for failure to appear in court.
   (D)   Alternative relief. Seeking a civil penalty as authorized in this
chapter does not preclude the city from seeking alternative relief from the
court in the same action. Such alternative relief may include, but is not
limited to, an order for abatement or injunctive relief.
   (E)   Criminal relief. This chapter does not preclude a peace officer from
issuing a criminal citation for a violation of the code of ordinances or
regulation if criminal penalties are also provided for the violation. Nor does
it preclude or limit the authority of the city to enforce the provisions of
this code of ordinances by criminal sanctions or other lawful means.
   (F)   Repeat offenders. A person receiving three enforcement letters for
code violations from an authorized official for the city within a 12-month
period, abated or otherwise, shall have committed a municipal infraction, is
declared a repeat offender, and shall be subject to the standard civil
penalties as provided for in this chapter.
(Ord. 2019-02, passed 2-18-2019; Ord. 2024-11, passed 8-19-2024)
§ 4.00 CONFLICTING PROVISIONS.
   If any sections of this code are in conflict with one another, the more
restrictive provision(s) shall apply.
§ 5.00 SEVERABILITY.
   If any chapter, section, provision or part of this code shall be judged
invalid or unconstitutional, such adjudication shall not affect the validity of
the code as a whole or any chapter, section, provision or part thereof not
judged invalid or unconstitutional.
§ 6.00 EFFECTIVE DATE.
   This code shall be in effect after its final passage, approval and
publication, as provided by law in Iowa Code Chapter 380.8.
§ 7.00 GENDER.
   All references contained in this code to masculine gender pronouns (he, his,
him) shall include the feminine gender.
§ 8.00 CITY OFFICERS.
   All references in this code to government officials or bodies (e.g., Clerk,
Council) are to those of the city, unless otherwise indicated by definition or
context.
§ 9.00 TERMINOLOGY; LAW.
   The term law, as used in this code, includes provisions of this code and
laws of the state (where applicable).
§ 10.00 REFERENCES TO IOWA CODE.
   References to the Iowa Code shall be to the 2024 code or supplement thereto.
§ 11.00 GENERAL APPEAL PROVISIONS.
   (A)   Any order properly given by any officer of the city acting pursuant to
his or her authority is appealable by the party affected upon written notice to
the ordering officer. Said officer shall give written notice to the appealing
party of a time and place at which the party may appear before the Council for
hearing on the matter, and said notice shall list the specific reason(s) for
the order, penalty, denial of license and the like. At the Council meeting, the
officer shall submit a written report stating the reason(s) for his or her
decision and the Council, after fair hearing, may reverse, amend, remand or
uphold the officer’s decision. Upon commencement of a good-faith appeal, the
order (or penalty and the like) in question shall be suspended until the
Council affirms the order after hearing of the public health or safety is, in
the Council’s determination, endangered. The Council’s decision shall be final
and any further contest of the matter must be pursued through the legal
process.
   (B)   This provision is intended to apply to all chapters within this code
unless the provisions of any chapter are more restrictive upon the city’s
actions.
§ 12.00 AMENDMENTS.
   All amendments to this code shall be accomplished in accordance with the
provisions of Iowa Code Chapter 380.
CHAPTER 3: CITY OFFICERS
Section
   
1.00   Mayor
   
2.00   Mayor Pro-Tem
   
3.00   City Council
   
4.00   City Administrator
   
5.00   Department supervisors
   
5.01   Responsibilities
   
5.02   Authority
   
5.03   Roles and expectations
   
6.00   Special provisions
   
7.00   Professional appointments
   
8.00   Appointment process
   
8.01   Effectiveness
 
   This chapter defines the general organization of the city, establishes
various positions and sets forth what is expected from each element of the
total city personnel picture. The role of the Mayor and the City Council, the
key city staff positions and various special appointments are all defined. In
addition to this general definition, other portions of the code prescribe
specific duties and responsibilities. The compensation of all employees and
appointed officers and boards shall be set, from time to time, by resolution of
the City Council.
§ 1.00 MAYOR.
   The Mayor is the chief executive officer of the city. He or she is elected
at large for a four-year term, presides over Council meetings, signs on behalf
of the city and makes sure that Council policies are executed. The compensation
of the Mayor shall be an annual salary as set from time to time by resolution
of the City Council, which shall be paid in semi-annual installments. Among his
or her responsibilities are:
§ 1.01. Facilitation of policy implementation – making sure that the Council’s
intentions are understood and that Council’s goals, objectives and policies are
carried out;
§ 1.02. Presides at Council meetings – making sure that issues are enunciated,
that all viewpoints are fully heard and helps the Council define and take
actions appropriate to the situation;
§ 1.03. Representative of the city to public groups, to other governmental
bodies and to the public at large;
§ 1.04. Directs the business of the Council, including establishing committees,
making key appointments (Chief of Police, Mayor Pro-Tem), proposing other
appointments to the Council and ensuring a sound plan of organization for the
city; and
§ 1.05. Assists the Council in the formulation of goals, policies and
objectives, making use of staff and public inputs as well as his or her own
views as to the needs for Council action.
§ 2.00 MAYOR PRO-TEM.
   The Mayor Pro-Tem is Vice President of the Council. When the Mayor is absent
or unable to act, the Mayor Pro-Tem shall perform the Mayor’s duties, except
that the Mayor Pro-Tem may not appoint, employ or discharge officers or
employees without the approval of the Council. Official actions of the Mayor
Pro-Tem when the Mayor is absent or unable to act are legal and binding to the
same extent as if done by the Mayor. The Mayor Pro-Tem retains all of the
powers of a Council member.
§ 3.00 CITY COUNCIL.
   The city has a five member Council elected at large for four-year staggered
terms. The Council is the body having ultimate responsibility for all of the
affairs of the city. Its specific duties include the definition of city
actions, steps to fund those actions (budgeting), approval of payments, the
exercise of fiscal and management control and as the arbiter of all matters
affecting the city. Each member of the City Council shall be compensated, in an
amount as set from time to time by resolution, for each Council meeting and
Committee of the whole attended, and shall be paid in semi-annual installments.
To fulfill these duties, the Council has the following roles and
responsibilities:
§ 3.01. Governing body - acts on all matters affecting the city;
§ 3.02. Legislative policy making body - develops and passes such ordinances
and resolutions as may be needed to direct and control activities within the
city;
§ 3.03. Develops and approves budgets, thereby appropriating funds for the work
the city is to do;
§ 3.04. Establishes goals and major performance objectives;
§ 3.05. Sets the “tone” of governmental quality and excellence;
§ 3.06. Assists the Mayor and city staff in the accomplishment of their roles,
i.e., works as a part of the overall team rather than just a system of checks
and balances;
§ 3.07. Monitors city performance and service levels;
§ 3.08. Acts as a buffer between the city and its citizens, educating the
public on complex issues and molding and interpreting public opinion; and
§ 3.09. Maintain a far-sighted attitude, recognizing the city is a continuing
entity.
§ 4.00 CITY ADMINISTRATOR.
   (A)   The Administrator is responsible for the overall direction of all city
activities. He or she develops plans to carry out Council intentions, organizes
the work of departments, develops the staff needed to do the work, sets
priorities and makes sure work is done to high standards of quality and
performance.
   (B)   The Administrator has staff responsibility for finance, planning,
engineering, personnel, public relations, engineering and social services as
well as operations. He or she coordinates the work of the City Attorney and
Engineer as well as that of staff. However, the Administrator is the agent of
the Council and Mayor in all that is done. These responsibilities are
extensions of those of the elected officials and as such are done in close
cooperation and coordination with those officials.
   (C)   The expectations of the Administrator include the following roles:
§ 4.01. Manager and director of city operations, working with the Department
heads;
§ 4.02. Implementor of Council’s policies and programs;
§ 4.03. Provider of feedback to Council regarding goals, programs and
operations;
§ 4.04. Developer of options with respect to problems, policies and programs;
§ 4.05. Sounding board for Council and Mayor;
§ 4.06. “Professional” budget and management systems developer;
§ 4.07. Assistant in clarifying and maintaining roles of Mayor, Council and
Administrator and demander of “excellence” from Council just as Council is a
demander of excellence from city staff;
§ 4.08. Innovator - provides new ideas for improvement of city’s operations and
productivity; and
§ 4.09. Developer and encourager of a working environment designed to achieve
the best results from the efforts of city employees.
§ 5.00 DEPARTMENT SUPERVISORS.
   The City Clerk, Chief of Police and Street Superintendent are considered as
department heads. As such, they have broad operating responsibilities within
their areas of concern. Section
5.02 defines their authority, §
5.01 defines those major responsibilities and § 5.03 deals with their roles and
relationships to other officers and to the city employees.
§ 5.01 RESPONSIBILITIES.
   (A)   The City Clerk. The City Clerk is responsible for the operation of
City Hall, collection of revenues, disbursements upon Council approval, proper
accounting for all funds, official records of city proceedings and the
execution of Council resolutions and directions regarding public notices, sales
of bonds and the like.
   (B)   The Chief of Police. The Chief of Police is in charge of the broad
area of public safety/public order. As such, he or she schedules and directs
uniformed officers, coordinates work with other law enforcement agencies, cares
for assigned equipment and enforces the laws of the city and the state.
   (C)   The Street Superintendent. The Street Superintendent is responsible
for the major functions of street maintenance, storm sewer and sanitary sewer
mains and supervises the work of city employees when they are performing work
in those areas. Included in this responsibility is operation of the city garage
and care of city equipment.
§ 5.02 AUTHORITY.
   (A)   Authority. Department supervisors are granted broad authority to carry
out routine operations within the limitations imposed by the budget. Work items
which are not of a recurring nature shall be approved by the Council even when
an appropriation for such work exists.
   (B)   Exceptions. Department supervisors are granted the authority to
approve general engineering costs up to $5,000 for any project directly related
to daily operations or public facility improvement planning with the approval
of the City Administrator.
   (C)   Specific authority. In addition to this general authority, specific
authority is granted these individuals by other sections of this code through
the appointment of these individuals to positions or jobs enumerated in §
5.00 of this chapter.
(Ord. 2023-17, passed 8-21-2023)
§ 5.03 ROLES AND EXPECTATIONS.
   (A)   Each of these key staff positions is expected to fulfill the following
roles as these relate to the specific areas of responsibility.
   (B)   These include:
      (1)   Positive supervision of city employees - organization of work and
responsibility of the Department in such a way as to make maximum use of the
abilities of other city employees;
      (2)   Responsive, considerate attention to all contacts with city
citizens, including a willingness to assist the public in concerns which may
not be a part of the specific duties of the job;
      (3)   Direct association with the Mayor and Council in securing their
approval when needed and to make it easier for the elected officials to fulfill
their responsibilities;
      (4)   Close coordination with other staff members characterized by the
view toward what an individual department can contribute to the overall benefit
of the city;
      (5)   High performance expectations for the Department Head and for other
employees; and
      (6)   Carefully planned work to make sure resources are efficiently used
and work is done correctly.
§ 6.00 SPECIAL PROVISIONS.
   (A)   The following are jobs which are appointments made by the Mayor with
the approval of the City Council. These appointments may be made of city
employees, members of the Council or Boards/Commissions or may be made of any
city resident.
   (B)   These appointments are:
      (1)   Zoning Administrator;
      (2)   Building Official/Building Inspector;
      (3)   Electrical Inspector;
      (4)   Plumbing Inspector;
      (5)   Heating and air conditioning inspector;
      (6)   Emergency management representative;
      (7)   City arborist; and
      (8)   Assistant/associate appointments to the above and to department
head positions.
§ 7.00 PROFESSIONAL APPOINTMENTS.
   The City Council shall appoint each year at the first meeting in January a
City Engineer, City Attorney and official depository, each of which shall be
fully qualified for such an appointment.
§ 8.00 APPOINTMENT PROCESS.
   In order to be eligible for a board or commission, an individual must reside
in the city and maintain residency within the city limits throughout his or her
term. Failure to reside in the city or maintain residency will result in
ineligibility or vacancy. Vacancies on the city’s various boards and
commissions shall be filled through the following process.
   (A)   The public shall be informed of the vacancy by published notice.
   (B)   Applicants will be given two weeks to submit their name to the City
Clerk for consideration.
   (C)   Applicants are required to reside in the city at the time of
application and maintain residency within the city limits throughout their
term.
   (D)   The Mayor will interview candidates.
   (E)   The Mayor will present a biography of the preferred candidate at
meeting of the committee of whole.
   (F)   The Council shall have the option of meeting the candidate.
   (G)   The Mayor will nominate the desired applicant for Council approval.
   (H)   The appointment process should be complete within a 30-day time
period.
(Ord. 2024-06, passed 2-19-2024)
§ 8.01 EFFECTIVENESS.
   Effective upon passage of this chapter, the terms for the Park Board shall
expire on the last day of February instead of the last day of December. The
terms of all persons serving on the Park Board and Utility Board at the time of
passage of this chapter shall have their term extended two months to the last
day of February of the year following that year in which their term was set to
expire.
(Ord. 2024-06, passed 2-19-2024)

§ 1.00 ESTABLISHMENT AND PURPOSE.
   (A)   There is hereby created an administrative agency to be hereinafter
known as the City Electric and Water Utility Board.
   (B)   The purpose of the City Electric and Water Utility Board is to provide
for the orderly management of municipal utilities in the city.
   (C)   The management and control of the waterworks and the electric light
and power plant of the city shall be from the effective date of this code,
under the management and control of the Board.
§ 2.00 METHOD OF APPOINTMENT OF THE BOARD.
§ 2.01 APPOINTMENT.
   The Board shall be appointed by the Mayor and approved by the City Council.
§ 2.02 ELECTRIC AND WATER UTILITY BOARD.
   The City Electric and Water Utility Board shall have five members. The
appointments shall be on a staggered basis, and the terms shall be for six
years. The initial staggering shall be as follows.
   (A)   The term of the member serving until January 1, 2003 shall remain
unchanged.
   (B)   The term of the member appointed January 2, 2000 shall expire on
January 1, 2003.
   (C)   The term of the member appointed January 2, 2001 shall expire on
January 1, 2006.
   (D)   The term of the member appointed January 2, 2002 shall expire on
January 1, 2006.
   (E)   The initial term of the fifth member shall expire January 1, 2007.
§ 2.03 CHAIRPERSON.
   The Board shall elect a Chairperson who shall preside over the Board
meetings. That term shall be established by the Board.
§ 2.04 ANNUAL REPORT.
   An annual report of all receipts and expenditures shall be made to the City
Council at the close of each fiscal year by the Board.
§ 2.05 ACCOUNTS.
   The Board shall establish a separate account or accounts for the purpose of
the municipal utilities under its jurisdiction. Money may be paid out of said
account only at the direction of a majority of the Board.
§ 3.00 ADMINISTRATION.
§ 3.01 ESTABLISHING RULES.
   The Electric and Water Utility Board shall establish such rules, bylaws and
procedures as are consistent with the Iowa Code.
§ 3.02 REMOVAL.
   Board members may be removed for cause by the Council upon written notice of
charges to that member and after public hearings.
§ 3.03 EMPLOYEES AND OFFICIALS INELIGIBLE.
   No city employee or official shall be eligible for Board membership.
Employees and elected officials shall remain ineligible for six months after
leaving city employment or leaving office.
§ 3.04 SECRETARY.
   The Board shall appoint or employ a secretary. If the Secretary is employed
and is someone other than a Board member, he or she shall have no vote. The
Board shall set the Secretary’s compensation.
§ 3.05 SHARED EQUIPMENT COST.
   The cost of shared equipment shall be allocated between the city and the
Utility Board according to proportional use.
§ 3.06 COMPENSATION OF EMPLOYEES.
   The compensation of employees who work for both the city and the Utility
Board shall be set by resolution by the Board.
§ 3.07 COMPENSATION OF BOARD.
   The compensation of Board members shall be set by the City Council by
resolution.
CHAPTER 5: PARK AND RECREATION BOARD
Section
   
1.00   Establishment and purpose
   
2.00   Powers and responsibilities
   
3.00   Administration of Park and Recreation Board
   
3.01   Qualifications of members
   
3.02   Term of office
   
3.03   Chairperson
   
3.04   Removal of members
   
4.00   Meetings
   
5.00   Budget
   
6.00   Bonds
   
7.00   Accumulations of funds
   
8.00   Salaries
§ 1.00 ESTABLISHMENT AND PURPOSE.
   A park and recreation board for the city is hereby created. Its general
responsibilities shall be to advise the Council on the needed facilities to
provide open space such as parks, playgrounds and community facilities for
other forms of recreation. It shall plan and oversee city programs, and
encourage other programs for the leisure of the city’s residents. It shall
maintain and operate any such facilities under its control, keeping a budget,
hiring employees and purchasing necessary equipment.
§ 2.00 POWERS AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The Park and Recreation Board shall have the following powers and duties:
§ 2.01. Promote community involvement and actively seek input in the planning,
operation and participation of the Parks and Recreation Board;
§ 2.02. Allow for an orderly growth, acquisition and development of the
physical and natural resources, and to utilize the natural characteristics of
the land, when evaluating its potential for Parks and Recreation purposes;
§ 2.03. More effectively coordinate the parks and recreation with other city
departments, organizations and schools to improve the overall service to the
community;
§ 2.04. Offer comprehensive, quality recreational programming aimed at
satisfying the needs of varying age levels, physical abilities and special
interests;
§ 2.05. Maintain and improve the appearance and safety of our parks and
facilities at the highest level of available resources;
§ 2.06. Provide efficient and effective leadership and coordination for quality
recreational and leisure activities for the community;
§ 2.07. Form partnerships with other public or private organizations, which
will expand human and financial assets for the community and encourage people
to volunteer their time and talents to enhance the city’s neighborhoods and
parks;
§ 2.08. To provide for the employment and compensation of Park and Recreation
employees for the operation of the facilities and to purchase recreational
equipment to be installed in said areas. The Park and Recreation Board is not
authorized to pledge the credit or tax powers of the city; and
§ 2.09. To draft rules and regulations concerning the use of the parks and
present such rules and regulations to the City Council. All rules and
regulations must be adopted by ordinance by the City Council.
§ 3.00 ADMINISTRATION OF PARK AND RECREATION BOARD.
   The Park and Recreation Board shall consist of five members and a Secretary-
Treasurer.
§ 3.01 QUALIFICATIONS OF MEMBERS.
   In order for a party to be qualified to serve on the Board, the individual
must be residing in the city.
§ 3.02 TERM OF OFFICE.
   Five members of the Board shall have full voting powers. Said members are to
be appointed by the City Council. Appointments shall be made on a staggered
basis, and the terms shall be for five years.
§ 3.03 CHAIRPERSON.
   The members of the Park and Recreation Board shall elect a chairperson on
the first annual meeting of each year. Said Chairperson shall be the liaison
officer between the Council and the Park and Recreation Board. In addition, the
Board shall elect a Chairperson Pro-Tem from the four remaining members.
§ 3.04 REMOVAL OF MEMBERS.
   (A)   Any Committee member who misses more than two regularly scheduled (or
special) Park and Recreation meetings during a quarter shall be subject to
removal for cause by the City Council. A quarter shall be defined as July
through September, October through December, January through March and April
through June.
   (B)   A Committee member subject to removal for cause shall receive notice
of the reasons for removal at least five days prior to the Council’s vote on
removal and shall be afforded an opportunity to show why he or she should not
be removed. Removal for cause shall occur upon a resolution, stating the reason
for the removal followed by a majority vote of the City Council. The removal is
effective upon the vote.
§ 4.00 MEETINGS.
   (A)   The meetings of the Park and Recreation Board shall be held on the
second week of each month in the City Hall. All such meetings shall be open to
the public, as required by the state law. Special meetings may be called by
three or more members or by the Chairperson, or requested by the City Council.
   (B)   Three or more of the appointed representatives for the purposes of
conducting a meeting constitute a quorum; said representatives do not include
the Secretary-Treasurer.
§ 5.00 BUDGET.
   The Board members should submit a proposed yearly operating budget prior to
February 1 to the City Council for approval so that the Board’s budget may be
included in the city’s budget. Income from government grant(s), donation(s) or
bequest(s) shall be available only for capital improvements or other uses
specified in the grant(s), donation(s) or bequest(s).
§ 6.00 BONDS.
   In the event that a bond issue is to be used in connection with the
improvements contemplated herein, the issue must be approved as provided by
state law. It is further agreed that all street, police and utility expenses,
not including capital improvements, in connection with the operation of the
park system therefor shall be part of the city’s General Expense Fund. All
records in connection with the operation of the Park Board shall be kept by the
Secretary-Treasurer separately from the city’s accounts. Quarterly reports of
the operation of the Board shall be submitted to the Council for approval.
§ 7.00 ACCUMULATIONS OF FUNDS.
   The Park and Recreation Board shall not accumulate any sums derived from
taxation in excess of 25% of the succeeding year’s budget. Any donations or
bequests not designated to particular projects should be utilized within two
years of the receipt of same. If, in fact, the funds derived from donations or
bequests are not used as set forth herein, said money shall be payable in trust
to a local banking institution, and distributed by its trust officer for those
purposes as set forth in §
2.00 of this chapter.
§ 8.00 SALARIES.
   The salaries of the members of the Park and Recreation Board and its
Secretary-Treasurer shall be set by the City Council by resolution. In the
event any member of the Board shall be required to travel outside the limits of
the city on official Park Board business, he or she shall be compensated for
expenses incurred. Expenses so incurred shall be included and projected in the
annual Park and Recreation Board budget.
CHAPTER 6: COMMUNITY CENTER BOARD
Section
   
1.00   Establishment and purpose
   
2.00   Powers and responsibilities
   
2.01   Operation of the community center
   
2.02   Employees and equipment
   
3.00   Administration of Community Center
   
3.01   Term of office
   
3.02   Chairperson
   
3.03   Removal of members
   
4.00   Meetings
   
5.00   Budget
   
6.00   Bonds
   
7.00   Salaries
§ 1.00 ESTABLISHMENT AND PURPOSE.
   A community center board for the city is hereby created. Its general
responsibilities shall be to:
   (A)   Maintain and operate the Eldridge Community Center;
   (B)   Keep a budget;
   (C)   Hire employees; and
   (D)   Purchase necessary equipment.
§ 2.00 POWERS AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The Community Center Board shall have the following powers and duties:
§ 2.01 OPERATION OF THE COMMUNITY CENTER.
   The responsibility for the operation, upkeep and development of the
Community Center; and
§ 2.02 EMPLOYEES AND EQUIPMENT.
   To determine the employment and compensation of employees for the operation
of the facility and to purchase equipment to be installed in the Community
Center. The Community Center Board is not authorized to pledge the credit or
tax powers of the city.
§ 3.00 ADMINISTRATION OF COMMUNITY CENTER.
   The Community Center Board shall consist of five members.
§ 3.01 TERM OF OFFICE.
   Five members of the Board shall have full voting powers. Said members are to
be appointed by the City Council. Appointments shall be made on a staggered
basis and the terms shall be for four years.
§ 3.02 CHAIRPERSON.
   The members of the Community Center Board shall elect a chairperson on the
first annual meeting of each year. Said Chairperson shall be liaison officer
between the Council and the Community Center Board. In addition, the Board
shall elect a Chairperson Pro-Tem from the four remaining members.
§ 3.03 REMOVAL OF MEMBERS.
   (A)   Any Community Center Board member who misses more than two regularly
scheduled (or special) meetings during a quarter shall be subject to removal
for cause by the City Council. A quarter shall be defined as July through
September, October through December, January through March and April through
June.
   (B)   A Board member subject to removal for cause shall receive notice of
the reasons for removal at least five days prior to the Council’s vote on
removal and shall be afforded an opportunity to show why he or she should not
be removed. Removal for cause shall occur upon a resolution, stating the reason
for the removal followed by a majority vote of the City Council. The removal is
effective upon the vote.
§ 4.00 MEETINGS.
   The meetings of the Community Center Board shall be held on the second
Wednesday of each month at a place designated by the Board. All such meetings
shall be open to the public, as required by state law. Special meetings may be
called by three or more members or by the Chairperson, or requested by the City
Council. Three or more of the appointed representatives for the purposes of
conducting a meeting constitute a quorum.
§ 5.00 BUDGET.
   The Community Center is intended to be an Enterprise Fund of the city, and
as such, the proceeds of the Center shall be kept separate and distinct from
the other funds of the city. Board members should submit a proposed yearly
operating budget prior to January 15 to the City Council for approval so that
the Board’s budget may be included in the city’s budget. Income from all
sources shall be included in the budget estimate. All bills of the Community
Center shall be submitted to the City Clerk to be drawn against the funds of
the Community Center. All proceeds of the Center shall be submitted to the City
Clerk who shall credit the proceeds to the Community Center account and deposit
them with an approved financial institution.
§ 6.00 BONDS.
   In the event that a bond issue is to be used in connection with the
improvements contemplated herein, the issue must be approved as provided by
state law. It is further agreed that all street, police and utility expenses,
not including capital improvements, in connection with the operation of the
Community Center, therefore shall be part of the city’s General Expense Fund.
§ 7.00 SALARIES.
   The salaries of the members of the Community Center Board shall be set by
the City Council by resolution. In the event any member of the Board shall be
required to travel outside the limits of the city on official community center
business, he or she shall be compensated for expenses incurred. Expenses so
incurred shall be included and projected in the annual Community Center budget.
CHAPTER 7: PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION
Section
   
1.00   Members
   
2.00   Comprehensive plan
   
3.00   Removal from Commission
   
4.00   Notice of removal
§ 1.00 MEMBERS.
   There shall exist in the city a planning and zoning commission composed of
seven residents of the city who shall be qualified, by knowledge and
experience, to act in matters pertaining to the development of city planning
and zoning.
§ 2.00 COMPREHENSIVE PLAN.
   The Planning and Zoning Commission shall prepare a comprehensive plan of the
city to promote the welfare of its residents in a manner consistent with the
police power granted to the cities in the Iowa Code and such Commission shall
make recommendations to the City Council for changes or modifications to the
city plan. (Also see
Title D, Chapter 2, §§
10 through
19.)
§ 3.00 REMOVAL FROM COMMISSION.
   Any Planning and Zoning Commission member who misses more than two regularly
scheduled (or special) meetings during a quarter shall be subject to removal
for cause by the City Council. A quarter shall be defined as July through
September, October through December, January through March and April through
June.
§ 4.00 NOTICE OF REMOVAL.
   A Commission member subject to removal for cause shall receive notice of the
reasons for removal at least five days prior to the Council’s vote on removal
and shall be afforded an opportunity to show why he or she should not be
removed. Removal for cause shall occur upon a resolution, stating the reason
for the removal followed by a majority vote of the City Council. The removal is
effective upon the vote.
CHAPTER 8: BOARD OF ADJUSTMENT
Section
   
1.00   Members
   
2.00   Appointment and removal
   
3.00   Powers
   
4.00   Removal from Board
   
5.00   Notice of removal
§ 1.00 MEMBERS.
   There shall exist in the city a board of adjustment composed of five
citizens of the city. A majority of the members of the Board of Adjustment
shall be persons representing the public at large and shall not be involved in
the business of purchasing or selling real estate. One member of the Board
shall be a member of the City Planning and Zoning Commission.
§ 2.00 APPOINTMENT AND REMOVAL.
   Members of the Board shall be appointed for a term of five years, excepting
that when the Board shall first be created, one member shall be appointed for a
term of five years, one for a term of four years, one for a term of three
years, one for a term of two years and one for a term of one year. The Board
shall not carry out its business without having three members present. Members
shall be removable for cause by the appointing authority upon written charges
and after public hearing. Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term of
any member whose term becomes vacant.
§ 3.00 POWERS.
   The powers of the Board shall be as set forth in
Title D, Chapter 2, § 12A.00.
§ 4.00 REMOVAL FROM BOARD.
   Any Board of Adjustment member who misses more than two regularly scheduled
(or special) meetings during a quarter shall be subject to removal for cause by
the City Council. A quarter shall be defined as July through September, October
through December, January through March and April through June.
§ 5.00 NOTICE OF REMOVAL.
   A Board member subject to removal for cause shall receive notice of the
reasons for removal at least five days prior to the Council’s vote on removal
and shall be afforded an opportunity to show why he or she should not be
removed. Removal for cause shall occur upon a resolution, stating the reason
for the removal followed by a majority vote of the City Council. The removal is
effective upon the vote.
CHAPTER 9: CODE REVIEW BOARD
Section
   
1.00   Members
   
2.00   Appointment and removal
   
3.00   Purpose
   
4.00   Powers
   
5.00   Removal from Board
   
6.00   Notice of removal
§ 1.00 MEMBERS.
   There shall exist in the city a code review board composed of nine members.
The membership of the Board shall be comprised of a mixture of people from the
various building trades, engineering disciplines and the public at large.
§ 2.00 APPOINTMENT AND REMOVAL.
   Members of the Board shall be appointed for a term of five years, excepting
that when the Board shall first be created, three members shall be appointed
for a term of five years, three members for a term of four years and three
members for a term of three years. The Board shall not carry out its business
without having five members present. Members shall be removable for cause by
the appointing authority upon written charges and after public hearing.
Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term of any member whose term
becomes vacant.
§ 3.00 PURPOSE.
   The Board shall act in the following capacities:
   (A)   To advise the City Council on the adoption of the various model
building codes;
   (B)   To review the various contractor licenses; and
   (C)   To review requests for interpretation of the various adopted model
building codes and to render decisions on appeals to interpretations of the
adopted construction codes.
§ 4.00 POWERS.
   More detail on the powers of the Board shall be found in
Title C, Chapter 8.
§ 5.00 REMOVAL FROM BOARD.
   Any Code Review Board member who misses more than two regularly scheduled
(or special) meetings during a quarter shall be subject to removal for cause by
the City Council. A quarter shall be defined as July through September, October
through December, January through March and April through June.
§ 6.00 NOTICE OF REMOVAL.
   A Board member subject to removal for cause shall receive notice of the
reasons for removal at least five days prior to the Council’s vote on removal
and shall be afforded an opportunity to show why he or she should not be
removed. Removal for cause shall occur upon a resolution, stating the reason
for the removal followed by a majority vote of the City Council. The removal is
effective upon the vote.
CHAPTER 10: BUSINESS LICENSES
Section
   
1.00   Purpose
   
2.00   License required
   
3.00   Businesses covered and excluded
   
4.00   Insurance
   
5.00   Not transferable or assignable
   
6.00   Revocation
   
7.00   Annual report
   
8.00   Appeal
   
9.00   Operation without a license prohibited
   
10.00   Applicability
§ 1.00 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to protect the general health and welfare of
the citizens of the city by regulating the public or semi-public premises
within the city.
§ 2.00 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   Except as hereinafter provided, any business located within the city must
possess a business license issued by the city.
§ 3.00 BUSINESSES COVERED AND EXCLUDED.
   The businesses required to be licensed hereunder include, but are not
limited to, any individual, partnership, association or corporation engaged in
the sale of goods, services or adult entertainment, whether at retail or
wholesale, done for the purpose of pecuniary profit or engaged in the
maintenance of any premises for use as an office, garage, warehouse,
manufacturing, assembly or processing facility for the use of the public or by
employees of the business. Business licenses are not required for traditional
neighborhood activities that are not publicly promoted and that are on a small
scale, such as baking, ironing, sales of handicrafts, newspaper carriers,
cosmetic products and the like; nor are business licenses required for sales or
service businesses that do not store, warehouse or make deliveries within the
corporate limits of the city.
§ 4.00 INSURANCE.
   The license herein required shall be obtained from the City Clerk upon
completion of an application form and approval thereof by the City Clerk and
Mayor. Before issuance of the license, the Zoning Enforcement Officer and the
Building Inspector shall have certified that the business complies with all
applicable zoning and building code regulations. The application shall be
accompanied by payment of a $10 fee.
§ 5.00 NOT TRANSFERABLE OR ASSIGNABLE.
   Any business license issued hereunder is not transferable or assignable. A
new business license shall be obtained upon any change in the location,
ownership, name or nature of the business.
§ 6.00 REVOCATION.
   A business license may be revoked by the Mayor if, in his or her judgment,
any business conducted or to be conducted under and by virtue of a license is
or will be detrimental to the public health or morals or liable to lead to the
violation of any ordinance or law, or provoke a breach of the peace, or if any
licensee or any of his or her agents makes any false or misleading statements
or representations in the furtherance of the business conducted under said
license or violates any ordinance or law in the conduct of the business for
which such license is issued.
§ 7.00 ANNUAL REPORT.
   Before July 1 of each year, each licensee shall complete and file with the
City Clerk a report on a form provided by the Clerk. The information required
on the annual report shall include, at a minimum, the following: name(s),
address(es) and telephone number(s) of the owners of the business, of the
business itself and of the person to contact in case of emergency, as well as a
description of the nature of the business. No fee shall be required for filing
the annual report. Failure to file the annual report shall be grounds for
revocation of the business license.
§ 8.00 APPEAL.
   Any person objecting to the issuance, non-issuance or revocation of a
business license will be heard at a meeting of the City Council. The Council
shall review the matter and make a final decision.
§ 9.00 OPERATION WITHOUT A LICENSE PROHIBITED.
   No person, firm or corporation shall engage in any business for which a
license is required by this chapter without first having obtained the necessary
license or licenses. Any person, firm or corporation who conducts a business
without first procuring a license is guilty of a simple misdemeanor and, upon
conviction, shall be fined not less than $25 nor more than $100.
§ 10.00 APPLICABILITY.
   This chapter shall apply to all licenses applied for or renewed after the
effective date of the ordinance incorporated herein this chapter. This chapter
shall further apply to all businesses which are required to be licensed but
which are not licensed as of the effective date of this chapter or which begin
doing business in the city after the effective date of the ordinance
incorporated herein this chapter.
CHAPTER 11: PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS
Section
   
1.00   Definitions
   
2.00   License required
   
3.00   License - application
   
4.00   License - issuance
   
5.00   License - fees
   
6.00   License - bond
   
7.00   Duplicate and individual licenses, when required
   
8.00   License - display
   
9.00   Charitable and non-profit organizations
   
10.00   Exemptions
   
11.00   Denial or revocation of license - procedure
   
12.00   Sales regulations
   
13.00   Penalty
§ 1.00 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   PEDDLER. Any person carrying or transporting goods or merchandise who sells
or offers for sale for immediate delivery such goods or merchandise from house
to house or upon the public street.
   SOLICITOR. Any person who solicits, or attempts to solicit, from house to
house or upon the public street an order for goods or merchandise to be
delivered at a future date.
   TRANSIENT MERCHANT. Any person, firm or corporation who engages in a
temporary or itinerant merchandising business, intending to remain in business
in the city for less than one year, and, in the course of such business, hires,
leases or occupies any building or structure whatsoever. Temporary association
with a local merchant, dealer, trader or auctioneer, or conduct of such
transient business in connection with, as a part of or in the name of any local
merchant, dealer, trader or auctioneer shall not exempt any person, firm or
corporation from being considered a TRANSIENT MERCHANT.
§ 2.00 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in peddling, soliciting or in
the business of a transient merchant in this city without first obtaining a
license as provided in this chapter.
§ 3.00 LICENSE - APPLICATION.
   An application for a license under this chapter shall be made with the City
Police Chief, or his or her authorized representative, and shall give the
following information:
   (A)   The name or names of the person or persons having the management or
supervision of applicant’s business during the time that it is proposed it will
be carried on in the city and the local address or addresses of such person or
persons while engaged in such business;
   (B)   The name and permanent address of the applicant; whether such person
will act as proprietor, agent, consignee or employee and the credentials
establishing such relationship; the name and address of the person, firm or
corporation for whose account the business will be carried on, if any; and if a
corporation, under the laws of what state the same is incorporated;
   (C)   The place or places in the city where it is proposed to carry on
applicant’s business and the length of time during which it is proposed said
business shall be conducted;
   (D)   A statement of the nature and character of the tangible personal
property or service to be sold or offered for sale by the applicant in the
city; whether the goods are new, damaged or rejects; whether the same are
proposed to be sold from stock in possession or by sample, or at auction, or by
direct sale, or by taking orders for future deliveries; where the goods or
property proposed to be sold are manufactured or produced and where such goods
or products are located at the time said application is filed;
   (E)   The place or places other than the permanent place of business of the
applicant, where applicant within three years preceding the date of said
application peddled, solicited or conducted a transient business, stating the
nature thereof and giving the post office box number and street address of any
building or office in or from which said business was conducted;
   (F)   Whether or not the applicant or the person having management or
supervision of the applicant’s business has been convicted of a felony within
the five years immediately preceding the date of the application or of the
violation of any laws or ordinance relating to the same or similar business
proposed to be conducted by the applicant, the nature of such offense and the
punishment therefor;
   (G)   Whether the applicant has ever applied for a license under this
chapter which has been denied;
   (H)   Whether the applicant has ever held a license under this chapter which
has been revoked;
   (I)   A physical description of the applicant, setting forth the applicant’s
age, height, weight, color of hair and eyes, social security number, driver’s
license number and state issued, a photograph of the applicant and the right
thumbprint of the applicant; and
   (J)   (1)   If the applicant’s business is to be conducted through
employees, the application shall include the information specified at divisions
(E) through (I) above, inclusive, for each employee who will be conducting
applicant’s business in this city as well as the name and address of each such
employee; and
      (2)   A non-refundable fee of $5 shall be paid at the time of filing such
application to cover the cost of investigating the facts set forth therein.
§ 4.00 LICENSE - ISSUANCE.
   If the Chief of Police finds the application is made out in conformance with
this chapter and the facts stated therein are correct, he or she shall issue,
within ten days and upon the posting of a bond as required by this chapter, a
license and charge a fee therefor, as determined by this chapter. The license
issued hereunder shall not be transferrable. There shall be no refund of the
license fee.
§ 5.00 LICENSE - FEES.
   Before a license shall be issued, the applicant shall pay a license fee in
accordance with the following schedule:
   (A)   For one day: $10; for each additional day: $2;
   (B)   For one month: $50;
   (C)   For six months: $100;
   (D)   For one year: $150; and
   (E)   For duplicate license: $2.
§ 6.00 LICENSE - BOND.
   Before a license under this chapter shall be issued, each applicant shall
post a bond of $100 with the Chief of Police. Such bond shall be conditioned
that the applicant shall comply with the provisions of all the ordinances of
the city and the statutes of the state regulating and concerning the sale of
goods, subscriptions, wares, merchandise or personal property of any nature,
including foodstuffs, or for services, including advertising, and will pay all
judgments rendered against the applicant for any violation of ordinances or
statutes or any of them together, with all judgments and costs that may be
recovered against said applicant by any person or persons for damage growing
out of any misrepresentation or deception practiced on any person who transacts
such business with the applicant, whether said misrepresentation or deception
was made or practiced by the owners or by their servants, agents or employees,
either at the time of making the sale, or the solicitation of the sale, or
through any advertisements of any character whatsoever, printed or circulated
with reference to the subject matter of such sale or any part thereof. Action
on the bond may be brought in the name of the city to the use of the aggrieved
person. Such bond shall be further conditioned to indemnify and pay the city
for any penalties or costs occasioned by the enforcement of this chapter and
shall not be retired until after a lapse of one year from the expiration of
each license.
§ 7.00 DUPLICATE AND INDIVIDUAL LICENSES, WHEN REQUIRED.
   A license under this chapter may be issued to a person carrying on the
business of solicitor, peddler or transient merchant in this city through
employees. Such employees shall carry a duplicate license issued to the
employee, which license shall be obtained at the office of the Chief of Police
upon compliance with the requirements of the chapter. If the business of
solicitor, peddler or transient merchant in this city is carried on through
agents who are not employees, or by consignees, or by an unincorporated firm or
association, each person so conducting the business in this city shall be
required to have a separate license, but not post a separate bond if one is
posted by the corporation.
§ 8.00 LICENSE - DISPLAY.
   Each solicitor or peddler shall, at all times while doing business in this
city, keep in his or her possession the license provided for by this chapter
and shall, upon the request of prospective customers, exhibit the license as
evidence of compliance with all requirements of this chapter. Each transient
merchant shall display publicly the license in his or her place of business.
§ 9.00 CHARITABLE AND NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS.
   (A)   Resident school, Girl Scout, Boy Scout and other such organizations
shall be exempt from the application of this chapter.
   (B)   (1)   A religious, charitable, patriotic, social service, civic or
political non-profit organization, other than those set forth in division (A)
above, shall receive a license for activities regulated under this chapter
where its authorized representative volunteers to undertake such activities
without remuneration and where the entire proceeds of the activities will go to
the organization and not for private profit.
      (2)   The organization shall file the information required for a license
under this chapter in the office of the Chief of Police. The Chief of Police
shall issue, free of charge and without bond, a license for the requested
activity which shall be valid for a period of one year and may be renewed on or
before the expiration date.
§ 10.00 EXEMPTIONS.
   Persons engaged in the following described activities are exempt from the
duty of applying for a license under this chapter:
   (A)   Persons selling at wholesale to merchants for the purpose of resale;
   (B)   Persons selling or distributing newspapers;
   (C)   Persons selling tangible personal property or services to business
enterprises;
   (D)   Persons who sell, at their permanent residence in the city, works of
art or craft made or created by such person or a member of each such person’s
immediate family;
   (E)   Persons licensed by the state to sell real estate or insurance or
licensed as transient vendors of drugs;
   (F)   Persons selling or distributing livestock feeds, as defined by the
laws of the state;
   (G)   Persons selling or delivering tangible personal property or services
through a permanent business licensed through the city;
   (H)   Persons selling or distributing fresh fruit or vegetables cultivated
by such person;
   (I)   Persons conducting and selling admissions to or for theatricals,
shows, rides, sports and games, concerts, circuses, carnivals or any other
public amusement where no sales of other products are involved and such sales
are made on the premises where the event is to be conducted;
   (J)   Persons selling tangible personal property at a garage, basement or
yard sale held at one of the persons’ premises; and
   (K)   Persons selling food and beverages at a food establishment regulated
pursuant to the Iowa Code.
§ 11.00 DENIAL OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE - PROCEDURE.
   (A)   Denial of license. The Chief of Police may deny, within ten days, a
license to any applicant who has:
      (1)   Held a license under this chapter that has been revoked within two
years of the date of the present application;
      (2)   Failed to make a complete, truthful application; and
      (3)   During the past two years, a history of:
         (a)   Fraudulent applications of similar licenses;
         (b)   Misrepresentation of the quality of merchandise or services
offered for sale; and
         (c)   Crimes involving personal property.
   (B)   Revocation of license. The Chief of Police may revoke any license
issued under the provisions of this chapter by sending a notice of revocation
by certified mail to the holder at his or her last known address, return
receipt requested, or by personal service on the license holder or its officers
for any of the following causes:
      (1)   Information showing the license was erroneously issued initially;
      (2)   For any violation of the provisions of this chapter;
      (3)   For any violation of any city or state law regulating the sales
activities of the license holder; and
      (4)   For making any fraudulent statement in connection with the
application for a license under this chapter.
   (C)   Hearings.
      (1)   The license shall stand denied or revoked, unless, within five days
after denial or receipt of the notice of revocation from the Chief of Police,
the license applicant or holder files a written request for a public hearing on
the Police Chief’s action. The public hearing shall be conducted before the
Public Safety Committee of the City Council which shall forward to the full
City Council a recommendation on whether a license should be denied, reinstated
or revoked, as the case may be. The City Council may order the license issued
or reinstated either conditionally or unconditionally, or revoke the license.
      (2)   Ten days’ notice of the time and place of the public hearing shall
be given to the license applicant or holder, who shall have an opportunity to
appear before the Committee and present any evidence or arguments he or she may
have why the action taken by the Chief of Police should not be approved by the
City Council.
§ 12.00 SALES REGULATIONS.
   (A)   No person shall engage in activities regulated under this chapter on
public property without first procuring special authorization from the City
Council.
   (B)   No person shall shout or use any sound device upon any of the public
places of the city or upon any private premises in said city where sound of
sufficient volume is emitted or produced therefrom to be capable of being
plainly heard from the public places, for the purpose of attracting attention
to any goods, wares, merchandise or services which such person proposes to
sell.
   (C)   No person shall engage in business under this chapter in defiance of
any notice exhibited at a residence or business indicating that peddlers or
solicitors are not welcome or are not invited.
   (D)   No person shall engage in the activities regulated under this chapter
from door-to-door, prior to 9:00 a.m. or after 8:00 p.m. on any weekday or
Saturday, or at any time on a Sunday or on a state or national holiday.
   (E)   A written receipt for all orders taken within the city shall be given
to the customer, which receipt shall be signed by the person making the sale
and shall set forth a brief description of the goods, wares, merchandise or
service or services ordered; the total purchase price thereof; and the amount
of the down payment received from the purchaser.
§ 13.00 PENALTY.
   (A)   Anyone violating the provisions of this chapter shall, upon
conviction, be subject to imprisonment not to exceed 30 days, or a fine not
exceeding $100.
   (B)   Each sale or solicitation of a sale made without a license or bond in
violation of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense.
CHAPTER 12: BEER LICENSING
