§ 3.02 BILLS.
   Bills are mailed on the first of each month and are due upon receipt. After
the twentieth of each month, a late penalty of 1.5% will be applied to the
bill.
(Ord. 2017-04, passed 6-5-2017; Ord. 2018-01, passed 2-19-2018; Ord. 2019-01,
passed 2-4-2019; Ord. 2020-01, passed 2-3-2020)
§ 3.03 INDUSTRIAL PRETREATMENT REQUIREMENTS.
   All discharges of wastewater, gases or solids which are not similar to
domestic sewage shall meet the following pretreatment requirements.
   (A)   This section adopts by reference the “General Pretreatment- Treatment
Regulations for Existing and New Sources of Pollution”, promulgated by the
United States Environmental Protection Agency, Title 40, Chapter I, Part 403,
as published in the Federal Register, Vol. 46, No. 18, Wednesday, January 28,
1981, and amended on April 7, 1993, as the city pretreatment regulation.
   (B)   (1)   Any industrial, commercial or other utility customer which
discharges any sewage, industrial waste or other waste to the municipal
sanitary sewer system shall comply with all regulations or requirements of the
State Department of Natural Resources and/or the United States Environmental
Protection Agency.
      (2)   Where regulations have not been set by those agencies, the Director
of Public Works shall establish pretreatment requirements to obtain the
following objectives:
         (a)   To prevent the introduction of pollutants which will interfere
with the treatment plant operation or contaminate the resulting sludge;
         (b)   To prevent the introduction of pollutants which will pass
through the system, inadequately treated, into the receiving waters or the
atmosphere or otherwise be incompatible with the system; and
         (c)   To improve opportunity to recycle and reclaim wastewater and
sludge from the system.
   (C)    Any costs for pretreatment flow measuring or monitoring facilities or
analytical systems or tests to meet the pretreatment regulations shall be the
responsibility of the customer.
   (D)   Any cost to the city, including increased operation or maintenance
expenditures or fines levied by the state or federal agencies, which result
from the discharge from any utility customer, shall be assessed to that
customer. In the event more than one utility customer is responsible, the cost
shall be prorated among those responsible based upon percent of total pounds of
pollutants.
   (E)   No utility customer may expand his or her process or operation if that
expansion results in a discharge or results in a discharge which exceeds any
limitation established for their discharges or results in the discharge of some
other substance which will violate any provision of the pretreatment
regulations unless their plans for expansion are approved by the Director of
Public Works at least six months prior to the planned expansion.
§ 4.00 EXCEPTIONS.
   Upon approval by the City Council, sewer charges shall be waived where the
water metered by a specific meter is used in such a way that it does not
normally enter the sanitary sewer system.
§ 5.00 SERVICE DISCONTINUED.
   Normal procedure shall be that sewer rentals continue during periods when a
building or apartment are vacant. In the event of an extended vacancy, sewer
rentals may be discontinued; but, in that event, a new connection charge shall
be made when the building or apartment is again occupied. Such a disconnection
shall be made only with the approval of the City Administrator.
§ 6.00 SCHOOLS.
   Sewer rates for school buildings and offices shall be the same as for
commercial/industrial users.
§ 7.00 CONNECTION CHARGES.
   A connection charge shall be paid for each new service connection to the
sewer system according to the schedule below. Connection fee will be collected
at the time a permit is obtained for the plumbing connection.
 
Residential $200 per bedroom
Commercial  $70 per 1,000 square feet
Industrial  $100 per 1,000 square feet
Commercial and industrial charges are determined by the intended use at the
time of new service, not zoning.
 
(Ord. 2020-01, passed 2-3-2020; Ord. 2021-02, passed 3-1-2021)
§ 8.00 IMPLEMENTATION GUIDELINES.
   The following guidelines shall apply in the establishment of sewer rates.
§ 8.01.   Sewer rentals are charged on the first of the month following the
provision of service.
§ 8.02.   Each apartment unit or grouping of sleeping rooms around a common
restroom facility shall be a residential sewer rental.
§ 8.03.   Each office or grouping of offices around common restroom facilities
shall be a commercial/industrial customer even under those circumstances where
more than one such grouping may be served by a single water meter.
§ 8.04.   Disputes over sewer rates and charges shall be resolved by the City
Council.
(Ord. 2024-13, passed 11-4-2024)
§ 9.00 SPECIAL TREATMENT REQUIREMENTS.
   Other ordinances require special or pre-treatment of other than domestic
type wastes. Such special treatment and all expense of monitoring and testing
such sewage shall be borne by the customer.
§ 10.00 STORM WATER DISPOSAL.
   No property owner or occupancy of any property which is connected to the
city’s sanitary sewer system shall knowingly allow storm water to enter the
sanitary sewer system by means of any part of the sewers or drains which are a
part of any structure or lot in said city. Specifically prohibited are
connections leading to the sanitary sewers from any sump pump or footing or
other sub-drains, as defined in the State Plumbing Code (1973), Chapter 13,
“Storm Drains”.

§ 1.00 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
§ 1.01.   ASHES. The residue of the combustion of solid fuels.
§ 1.02.   BUILDING DEBRIS. Any refuse or residue resulting from minor non-
commercial repairs to a private dwelling made by the owner or occupant thereof
himself or herself.
§ 1.03.   BUILDING WASTE. Any and all refuse or residue resulting directly from
building construction, reconstruction, repair or demolition; from grading,
shrubbing or other incidental work in connection with any premises; or from
replacement of building equipment or appliances.
§ 1.04.   BULK REFUSE. Articles more than eight feet in length or more than 50
pounds in weight, tree trimmings and hedge trimmings over five inches in
diameter or over four feet in length, tree roots or stumps larger than can be
contained in a bushel basket.
§ 1.05.   CITY WASTE COLLECTORS. Persons or firms employed by the city from
time to time to collect and dispose of household waste, institutional waste,
commercial waste or building debris from within the confines of the city.
§ 1.06.   COMMERCIAL WASTE. Garbage, rubbish, mixed refuse and cool ashes
originating in and around commercial establishments, industrial establishments,
hotels, restaurants, cafeterias, grocery stores, non-public institutions and
multiple housing facilities with more than two dwelling units.
§ 1.07.   DEAD ANIMALS. Animals that have died naturally or have been
accidently killed. Animals or parts of animals from slaughter houses are not
included in this category.
§ 1.08.   DEPARTMENT. The Department of Public Works of the City of Eldridge.
§ 1.09.   GARBAGE. All putrescible animal or vegetable wastes resulting from
the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food in any private
dwelling house, multiple dwelling, hotel restaurant, building or institution.
§ 1.10.   HAZARDOUS REFUSE. Any refuse the handling or disposal of which, in
the opinion of the Street Superintendent, would constitute a danger to city
employees or to city property.
§ 1.11.   HOUSEHOLD WASTE. Garbage, rubbish, recyclable material, mixed refuse
and cool ashes originating in and around private dwellings and multiple
dwellings, excluding multiple housing facilities with more than two dwelling
units.
§ 1.12.   INDUSTRIAL WASTE. Any and all residue resulting directly from
industrial or manufacturing operations. It shall not include waste originating
from commercial operations of an industrial establishment, nor shall it include
waste resulting from the commercial operation of persons, firms or corporations
engaged in the construction of buildings, the repairing of streets or
buildings, demolition or excavation. Residue or waste resulting from tree or
landscaping services shall also be excluded.
§ 1.13.   INSTITUTIONAL WASTE. Garbage, rubbish, mixed refuse and cool ashes
originating in and around tax exempt hospitals, excluding multiple housing
facilities with more than two dwelling units, and public, charitable,
philanthropic or religious institutions conducted for the benefit of the public
or a recognized section of the public. Institutions not covered by the
foregoing definition shall be considered commercial establishments.
§ 1.14.   LICENSED WASTE COLLECTOR. Any person, firm or corporation who has
obtained a license as specified herein from the city to collect or transport,
for a consideration, bulk refuse, household waste, institutional waste,
commercial waste, industrial waste, building waste or building debris,
regardless of the place of origin, over the streets of the city.
§ 1.15.   MIXED REFUSE. Garbage and rubbish placed and stored together.
§ 1.16.   PRIVATE WASTE COLLECTOR. Any person, firm or corporation who collects
bulk debris from premises owned or occupied by him or her within the
corporation limits of the city and transports said wastes over the streets of
the city.
§ 1.17.   RECYCLABLE MATERIAL. Material having an economic value in the
secondary materials market. RECYCLABLE MATERIAL shall include, but not be
limited to, cardboard, paper, magazines, newspaper, plastic containers, tin,
steel, aluminum, bi-metal cans and glass containers. Other material may become
recyclable as new markets develop. Such material will be determined by the
County Material Recovery Facility (MRF).
§ 1.18.   REFUSE. All solid wastes.
§ 1.19.   RUBBISH. All waste paper, rags, sweepings, small pieces of wood,
excelsior, rubber, leather, articles not more than eight feet in length nor
more than 50 pounds in weight, small rocks and similar waste materials that
ordinarily accumulate around a home, business or industry. It shall not include
garbage, ashes, bulk refuse, dead animals, hazardous refuse, industrial waste,
yard waste, recyclable material or building waste.
§ 1.20.   STREET SUPERINTENDENT. The Street Superintendent of the City of
Eldridge.
§ 1.21.   WHITE GOODS. Appliances which are durable in nature and which do not
readily degrade. Examples of WHITE GOODS shall include, but not be limited to,
washers, dryers, dishwashers, microwave ovens and refrigerators.
§ 1.22.   YARD WASTE. Debris such as grass clippings, leaves, garden waste,
brush and trees. YARD WASTE shall not include tree stumps.
§ 1.23.   YARD WASTE BAG. A special degradable bag as specified by the city
with not less than 20 gallon capacity and not more than 30 gallon capacity.
This bag shall be capable of decomposing within 60 days of exposure to aerobic
bacteria or ultraviolet light.
§ 2.00 RESPONSIBILITY.
   The city may employ persons or firms as city waste collectors and may
license private waste collectors. The Street Superintendent shall be
responsible for the collection, transportation and disposal of all refuse and
he or she is hereby authorized to adopt reasonable regulations to carry out the
intent of this chapter.
§ 3.00 PROHIBITED DISPOSITION.
   No person shall throw, litter, drop or deposit, or cause to be thrown,
dropped or deposited, within the confines of the city any refuse (including,
but not limited to, garbage, rubbish, ashes, bulk refuse, dead animals,
hazardous refuse, building waste or debris, putrescible matter or anything
injurious to health) on any premises, vacant property, street or alley, or
into, about, around or near any stream, ditch or body of water, regardless of
size; provided, however, that the prohibitions contained in this section shall
not apply to the depositing of refuse on a public disposal site nor to the
construction of embankments and the filling in or grading of property with
earth, mud and similar materials nor to refuse placed and stored for
collection. Garbage shall not be deposited in public wastepaper receptacles.
§ 4.00 BURNING REFUSE.
   No burning of paper or rubbish will be allowed within the city limits.
§ 5.00 COLLECTION OF REFUSE.
   It is hereby declared unlawful for anyone, except licensed waste collectors,
private waste collectors or city waste collectors, to collect refuse or
transport refuse over the streets of the city. It is further declared unlawful
to permit refuse to be collected by anyone, except licensed waste collectors,
private waste collectors or city waste collectors.
§ 6.00 STORING REFUSE.
   Each owner, tenant, housekeeper or other person, firm or corporation
producing or responsible for refuse shall provide sufficient containers or
other storage facilities to hold refuse accumulating therein so that such
refuse does not cause or create a nuisance or offensive odor or atmosphere or
rodent or fly harborage, or thereby to be or to become, or cause to create a
public nuisance. Containers for refuse and refuse not in containers shall be
stored on private property except on collection days. Notwithstanding the
above, garbage or mixed refuse shall not be retained for a period of time
longer than seven days on any premises, except a public disposal site
designated to receive garbage nor shall rubbish, ashes, bulk refuse, building
waste or building debris be retained for a period of time longer than 15 days
on any premises, except a public disposal site or any other legal site upon
which such refuse may be retained.
§ 7.00 CITY WASTE COLLECTION.
   City waste collectors shall collect and remove all household waste at least
once each week on such schedule as the Street Superintendent prescribes, when
such waste is prepared and stored as provided in this section. Yard waste shall
be prepared and collected separately. City waste collectors shall not collect
and remove bulk refuse, dead animals, hazardous refuse, industrial waste or
building waste, except as may be necessary in the enforcement of §
3.00 of this chapter. Refuse, garbage, rubbish, cool ashes and building debris
shall be separated and stored in separate containers except that garbage and
rubbish may be combined in a container as mixed refuse.
§ 8.00 PREPARATION OF REFUSE.
§ 8.01 GARBAGE.
   All garbage shall be thoroughly drained of its moisture and wrapped in
substantial paper or deposited in sanitary paper or plastic bags when placed in
containers for collection.
§ 8.02 RUBBISH.
   Rubbish shall have all liquids removed when placed in containers for
collection. Paper scraps, letters, sweepings, excelsior, rags and other similar
rubbish shall be dry and shall be secured in tight packages or plastic bags
when placed in containers for collection. Empty wooden crates in excess of four
feet for any dimension shall be knocked down when placed for collection.
§ 8.03 RECYCLABLE MATERIAL.
   (A)   Recyclable material shall be separated from garbage and refuse
accumulated on the premises.
   (B)   All plastic containers shall be rinsed, flattened and the lids
removed. All cans, regardless of type of metal composition, shall be rinsed and
flattened. Newspapers, magazines and paper shall be placed in paper sacks.
Cardboard shall be flattened and placed in paper sacks. Glass containers shall
be rinsed and have the lids removed.
§ 8.04 ASHES.
   Ashes shall be cool and dry when placed in containers for collection.
§ 8.05 YARD WASTE.
   (A)   Yard waste, as defined in §
1.22 of this chapter, shall be separated by the owner or occupant from all
other garbage and refuse accumulated on the premises.
   (B)   Yard waste shall be composed on the premises or placed in special
bags, marked as specified by the city. Such yard waste bags shall be collected
by the city as set forth in §
7.00 of this chapter.
§ 8.06 LEAD ACID BATTERIES.
   Such material shall not be included in the garbage and refuse accumulated on
the premises. Such material shall only be disposed of at drop-off points
designated by the city or the State Department of Natural Resources. Drop-off
points and provision regulating the points will be set forth by resolution.
§ 8.07 WASTE MOTOR OIL.
   Such material shall not be included in the garbage and refuse accumulated on
the premises. Such material shall only be disposed of at drop-off points
designated by the city or the State Department of Natural Resources. Drop-off
points and provision regulating the points will be set forth by resolution.
§ 8.08 TIRES.
   Such material shall not be included in the garbage and refuse accumulated on
the premises. Such material shall only be disposed of at drop-off points
designated by the city or the State Department of Natural Resources. Drop-off
points and provision regulating the points will be set forth by resolution.
§ 8.09 WHITE GOODS.
   Such material shall not be included in the garbage and refuse accumulated on
the premises. Such material shall only be disposed of at drop-off points
designated by the city or the State Department of Natural Resources. Drop-off
points and provision regulating the points will be set forth by resolution.
§ 9.00 CONTAINERS.
   Each owner, tenant, housekeeper or other person, firm or corporation
occupying any room dwelling, house, apartment, institution, commercial
establishment or any other building or portion hereof, and producing or
responsible for garbage, rubbish, recyclable material, mixed refuse, ashes,
yard waste or building debris which is intended to be collected by city waste
collectors shall provide a sufficient number of containers of the types as
specified herein to hold garbage, rubbish, mixed refuse, ashes or building
debris accumulating therein between collection periods. Any container that does
not conform to the following specifications or that may have ragged or sharp
edges or any other defect liable to hamper or injure the person collecting the
contents thereof must be promptly replaced upon receipt of notice to that
effect from the Street Superintendent to the responsible person or agent. If
the non-conforming or defective container is not replaced within ten days after
notice is served, such non-conforming or defective container shall be
considered rubbish and shall be collected and disposed of by the Department.
Containers shall meet the specifications in the section below.
§ 9.01 GARBAGE.
   A garbage container shall be a portable sanitary, watertight receptacle of
substantial construction with a close-fitting cover and adequate handles on the
receptacle and cover. The container shall be of such dimensions that it can be
easily handled by one person and in any case shall not have a capacity in
excess of 20 gallons nor weight more than 50 pounds when placed for collection.
§ 9.02 RUBBISH.
   Containers for rubbish shall be identical to garbage containers except as
otherwise specified herein. Containers for small rocks and other rubbish which
are not susceptible to being windblown may be bushel baskets, small metal
containers or similar containers that, when placed for collection, have a
weight not in excess of 50 pounds and which have adequate handles. Empty wooden
crates, tree roots and stumps all prepared as required herein need not be
placed in containers.
§ 9.03 MIXED REFUSE.
   Containers for mixed refuse shall be identical to garbage containers.
§ 9.04 ASHES.
   An ash container shall be a portable metal receptacle of substantial
construction with a close fitting cover and adequate handles on the receptacle
and cover. The container shall be of such dimensions that it can be easily
handled by one person and when placed for collection not weigh more than 50
pounds.
§ 9.05 BUILDING DEBRIS.
   Containers for building debris shall be identical to rubbish containers.
§ 9.06 YARD WASTE.
   Containers for yard waste shall be degradable bags, marked as specified by
the city.
§ 9.07 RECYCLABLE MATERIAL.
   (A)   Containers for recyclable material shall be a specially marked 18-
gallon container as specified by the city.
   (B)   Nothing in this section shall be interpreted as preventing the Street
Superintendent from approving other receptacles or devices that, in his or her
opinion, meet the requirements of §
8.03 of this chapter.
§ 10.00 COLLECTION.
   (A)   Where a property abuts a public alley, refuse prepared for collection
shall, on collection days, be placed together in plain view adjacent to the
alley. Where a property does not abut a public alley, refuse prepared for
collection shall, on collection days, be placed together in plain view adequate
to and in back of the curb line or on the shoulder of a public street. Refuse
shall be placed for collection prior to 7:30 a.m. of the day of collection but
in no case prior to 12 hours preceding the day of collection. All containers
shall be removed from a public street within 12 hours after refuse is
collected. Containers other than the type required for garbage (whether used
for garbage, rubbish, mixed refuse, ashes or building debris) will be collected
as rubbish unless clearly marked to be retained. City waste collectors shall
not enter houses, enclosed porches, garages or similar enclosures to make
collections nor shall city waste collection equipment enter private property to
make collections.
   (B)   Recyclable material shall be placed at the curb for collection. If
recyclable material is not separated from rubbish and garbage and placed for
collection in the appropriate place, the city waste collector has the right to
refuse to collect any refuse from that household until that household complies
with the separation requirements. Repeated violations may subject the household
to penalties as provided in §
16.00 of this chapter.
§ 11.00 NON-HOUSEHOLD WASTE.
   It shall be the duty of all establishments that produce institutional waste,
commercial waste and industrial waste to provide for the collection of all
solid waste produced on any such premises.
§ 12.00 RATES.
   The City Council shall hereby be empowered to enact by resolution, rate
schedules for sanitation pick-up for residential and commercial uses within the
limits of the city.
§ 13.00 GRATUITIES.
   Tips or gratuities shall not be offered to city employees to perform special
or unlawful service in connection with city waste collection. Solicitation of
tips or gratuities by city waste collectors is prohibited.
§ 14.00 LICENSED WASTE COLLECTION.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to collect refuse
within the city, except from premises within the city owned or occupied by him
or her, without first obtaining a license from the city. This requirement shall
not apply to city waste collectors.
§ 14.01 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   (A)   Application for a license to collect garbage and/or rubbish and/or
other refuse within the city and/or to transport garbage and/or rubbish and/or
other refuse over the streets of the city shall be made at the office of the
City Clerk on forms provided by said office. With his or her application, the
applicant shall file a certificate or affidavit of insurance as hereinafter set
forth and shall deposit the required license fee.
   (B)   Upon receipt of such application properly executed by the applicant,
the City Clerk shall refer same to the Street Superintendent for his or her
review and approval.
§ 14.02 INSPECTION BY STREET SUPERINTENDENT.
   (A)   Upon receiving the application from the City Clerk, the Street
Superintendent shall, as expeditiously as possible, make, or cause to be made,
an inspection of the applicant’s equipment proposed to be used, his or her
methods of operation, the pick-up service to be maintained and the certificate
or affidavit of insurance filed. If the Street Superintendent determines that
the applicant meets the requirements set forth herein, he or she shall file his
or her approval with the City Clerk. If the Street Superintendent Determines
that the applicant does not meet the requirements set forth herein, he or she
shall notify the applicant of the deficiencies of his or her application.
   (B)   The applicant shall have 30 days from the date of such notice of
deficiency from the Street Superintendent to the applicant to correct the
deficiency or deficiencies. If the deficiencies are corrected within this
period, the Street Superintendent, after making a further inspection, shall
file his or her approval with the City Clerk. If the deficiencies are not
corrected within this period, the Street Superintendent shall file his or her
disapproval with the City Clerk.
§ 14.03 ISSUANCE OR DENIAL OF LICENSE.
   (A)   Upon receipt of approval from the Street Superintendent, the City
Clerk shall issue the applicant a license. An applicant receiving such a
license is referred to herein as a “licensed waste collector”.
   (B)   Upon receipt of disapproval from the Street Superintendent, the City
Clerk shall notify the applicant that his or her application is denied. The fee
filed by an applicant whose application has been denied shall be retained by
the city and deposited in the Sanitation Fund.
   (C)   An applicant whose application has been denied may appeal such denial
to the City Council within 30 days from the date of the notice of denial. The
City Council may issue a license after review of the application and review of
the Street Superintendent’s disapproval.
§ 14.04 INSURANCE.
   The certificate or affidavit to be filed with the application shall be
executed by representatives of a duly qualified insurance company evidencing
that said insurance company has issued liability and property damage insurance
policies covering the following: first, all operations of the applicant, or any
other person, firm or corporation employed by him or her in garbage and refuse
collection and/or transportation within the corporate limits of the city;
second, the disposal of such garbage and refuse to and within any area
designated as a sanitary landfill by the city; third, protecting the public and
any person from injuries or damages sustained by reason of carrying on the work
of garbage and refuse collection and disposal. The certificate or affidavit
shall specifically evidence the following amounts of insurance coverage which
shall remain in effect for the term of the license, and shall provide that
written notice shall be given the City Clerk 30 days prior to any change in the
conditions of the certificate or affidavit, or any expiration or cancellation
thereof.
   (A)   Public liability insurance: $250,000 per person, $500,000 per
accident;
   (B)   Motor vehicle bodily injury liability: $250,000 per person, $500,000
per accident; and
   (C)   Property damage: $100,000 per accident.
§ 14.05 LICENSES.
   Each vehicle used by a licensee shall be licensed to be operated and shall
be operated only for the purpose(s) stated in the licensee’s application. A
license number for each vehicle approved shall be issued with each license and
shall be plainly displayed on the left front of each vehicle. A duly issued
license is not transferable from vehicle to vehicle or from collector to
collector. A license expires on December 31 of the year of issuance.
§ 14.06 LICENSE FEE.
   The license fee shall be $25 per license, plus $5 per year, per vehicle. If
issued after July 1 of any year, the license fee per vehicle for the remainder
of that year shall be $3 per vehicle.
§ 14.07 RENEWAL OF LICENSE.
   The annual license shall be renewed from year to year by making application
for renewal in the same manner as prescribed herein for making application for
license. Application may be made on or after December 1 of the year preceding
the year for which the license is required.
§ 14.08 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   The City Council may, for violation of requirements contained herein or for
violation of other city ordinances, revoke a duly issued license after notice
to the licensee affected.
§ 14.09 VEHICLES.
   (A)   Vehicles used by licensed waste collectors for the collection of
refuse from within the city and/or the transporting of refuse over the streets
of the city shall be of a type that the public health, safety or welfare shall
not be jeopardized by their use. Any vehicle used in the collecting or
transporting of refuse within the city shall be kept in a sanitary condition
and shall be so constructed and so used that no leakage or spillage occurs when
the vehicle is collecting or transporting refuse.
   (B)   Vehicles licensed for the purpose of collecting and/or transporting
garbage or mixed refuse shall be packer type trucks or other approved type
trucks.
   (C)   Vehicles licensed for the purpose of collecting and transporting
rubbish, ashes, bulk refuse, building waste and/or building debris shall be
tightly constructed and shall be equipped with a top or canvas cover, tailgate
and sideboards as required such that the contents will be retained therein and
will not spill, leak or blow out of the vehicles.
   (D)   Vehicles licensed for the purpose of collecting and transporting other
kinds of refuse shall be tightly constructed and shall be appropriate for the
collection and hauling of the particular kind of refuse being collected and
shall be approved by the Street Superintendent for such purpose.
§ 14.10 CONTAINERS.
   Each owner, tenant, housekeeper or other person, firm or corporation
occupying any room, dwelling, house, apartment, institution, commercial
establishment or any other building or portion thereof and producing refuse of
any kind which is intended to be collected by licensed waste collectors shall
provide sufficient containers to hold such refuse accumulating therein between
collection periods. A garbage or mixed refuse container shall be sanitary and
watertight with a close-fitting cover. Containers for all other refuse shall be
appropriate for the refuse contained therein.
§ 14.11 COLLECTION.
   Collection of garbage or mixed refuse by a licensed waste collector from any
room, dwelling, house, apartment, institution, commercial establishment or any
other building or portion thereof which he or she has agreed to service shall
be made not less than once each week.
§ 14.12 PICK-UP SERVICE.
   Each licensed waste collector shall maintain an adequate and prompt pick-up
service and to service all complaints from his or her patrons on missed service
and/or improper handling. Such service shall be promptly available for
servicing complaints from the city or any material improperly deposited within
the city.
§ 14.13 HAULING.
   All garbage and other refuse collected shall be transported such that no
leakage or spillage occurs. All refuse shall be contained within the vehicles
such that no refuse drags upon or makes contact with the roadway and such that
no refuse extends beyond the sides or ends of the vehicle while being hauled.
§ 14.14 DISPOSAL.
   All garbage and other refuse collected shall be disposed of at a sanitary
landfill site or other site approved by the Street Superintendent.
§ 14.15 CHARGES.
   Fees and rates for the collection of refuse by licensed waste collectors
shall be determined by said collector and not by the city and shall be charged
by said collector to the user of the licensed waste collector’s service.
§ 15.00 PRIVATE WASTE COLLECTION.
   Refuse may be collected and transported over the streets of the city by any
person, firm or corporation from premises owned or occupied by him or her
within the corporation limits of the city. Vehicles used by a private waste
collector for the collection and hauling of refuse shall be of a type such that
the public health, safety or welfare shall not be jeopardized by their use. All
refuse transported by a private waste collector shall be hauled such that no
leakage or spillage occurs, nor refuse drags upon or makes contact with the
roadway and no refuse extends beyond the sides or ends of the hauling vehicles.
All garbage and other refuse collected by a private waste collector shall be
disposed of at a sanitary landfill site or other site approved by the Street
Superintendent.
§ 16.00 VIOLATIONS.
   Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty
of a misdemeanor and subject to a fine of not more than $100 for each day of
violation or by imprisonment for not more than 30 days or both such fine and
imprisonment.
CHAPTER 4: PLANTING AND CARE OF TREES
Section
   
1.00   Purpose
   
2.00   Arboricultural specifications and standards of practice
   
2.01   Planting size
   
2.02   Planting grade
   
2.03   Placement
   
2.04   Method of support
   
2.05   Spacing
   
2.06   Trimming and pruning
   
3.00   Removal of trees
   
4.00   Duty to trim trees
   
5.00   Trimming of trees under supervision of Street Superintendent
   
6.00   Definitions
   
7.00   Trees interfering with utilities
   
8.00   Notice to remove trees
§ 1.00 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to beautify and preserve the appearance of
the city, by requiring street trees to be uniformly located and maintained. The
primary responsibility for maintaining street trees is placed upon the abutting
property owner or his or her agent, but the Street Superintendent shall
personally supervise any cutting or trimming of said trees.
§ 2.00 ARBORICULTURAL SPECIFICATIONS AND STANDARDS OF PRACTICE.
§ 2.01 PLANTING SIZE.
   All trees planted on the streets shall be of sufficient size to warrant
satisfactory results and stand the abuse common to street trees.
§ 2.02 PLANTING GRADE.
   Unless otherwise allowed for substantial reasons, all standard sized trees
shall have comparatively straight trunks, well-developed leaders and top and
root characteristics of the species or variety showing evidence of proper
nursery pruning. All trees must be free of insects, disease, mechanical
injuries and other objectionable features at the time of planting. To
compensate for any serious loss of roots, the top of the tree should be reduced
by thinning or cutting back as determined by the growth characteristics of the
tree species. The leader shall not be cut off in such trimming.
§ 2.03 PLACEMENT.
   Trees shall not be planted on the parking if it is less than nine feet in
width, or contains less than 81 square feet of exposed soil surface. Trees
shall not be planted closer than 20 feet to street intersections (property
lines extended) and ten feet to driveways. If it is at all possible, trees
should be planted inside the property lines and not between the sidewalk and
the curb.
§ 2.04 METHOD OF SUPPORT.
   Trees may be guyed or supported in an upright position according to accepted
arboricultural practices. The guys or supports shall be fastened in such a way
that they will not girdle or cause serious injury to the trees or endanger
public safety.
§ 2.05 SPACING.
   All trees hereafter planted in any street shall be planted midway between
the outer line of the sidewalk and curb. In the event a curb line is not
established, trees shall be planted not less than four feet inside the private
property line side of the sidewalk.
§ 2.06 TRIMMING AND PRUNING.
   All cuts are to be made sufficiently close to the parent stem so that
healing can readily start under normal conditions. All dead and diseased wood
shall be removed. All limbs one inch in diameter or more must be precut to
prevent splitting. All branches in danger of injuring the tree in falling shall
be lowered by ropes. A crossed or rubbing branch shall be removed where
practicable, but removal shall not leave large holes in the general outline of
the tree. Crossed or rubbing branches may be cabled apart. All cuts, old or
new, one inch in diameter or more, shall be painted with an approved tree wound
dressing. On old wounds, care shall be taken to paint exposed wood only. Where
there is a known danger of transmitting disease by tools, said tools shall be
disinfected with alcohol before use on another tree. Improperly healed scars,
where callous growth is not established, are to be traced and painted, unless
the Street Superintendent designates other treatment. No topping or dehorning
of trees shall be permitted except by special written permission of the Street
Superintendent. Trees becoming stag-headed may have the dead portions removed
back to sound green wood, with a proper 45 degree cut only. Elm wood trimmed,
pruned or removed shall not be used for any purpose, but shall be disposed of
immediately by burning or burying.
§ 3.00 REMOVAL OF TREES.
   The Street Superintendent shall remove, on the order of the Council, any
tree on the streets of this municipality which interferes with the making of
improvements or with travel thereon. If the abutting property owner refuses to
remove trees which have become diseased, or which constitute a danger to the
public, or which have been declared a nuisance, he or she shall be subject to
the penalties set out in §
8.00 of this chapter.
§ 4.00 DUTY TO TRIM TREES.
   The owner or agent of the abutting property shall keep the trees on, or
overhanging, the street trimmed so that all branches will be at least 13 feet
above the surface of the street and nine feet above the sidewalk.
§ 5.00 TRIMMING OF TREES UNDER SUPERVISION OF STREET SUPERINTENDENT.
   Except as allowed in §
4.00 of this chapter, no person may trim or cut any tree in a street or public
place unless the work is done under the personal supervision of the Street
Superintendent.
§ 6.00 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
§ 6.01.   PARKING. Includes that part of the street or avenue or highway in the
city not covered by sidewalk and lying between the lot line and the curb lines;
or, on unpaved streets, that part of the street, avenue or highway lying
between the lot line and that portion of the street usually traveled by
vehicular traffic.
§ 6.02.   PERSON. Includes any individual, firm, corporation, trust,
association or any other organized group.
§ 6.03.   PROPERTY OWNER. Includes a person owning private property in
Eldridge, Iowa.
§ 6.04.   PUBLIC PROPERTY. Includes any and all property located within the
confines of the city and owned by the city or held in the name of the city by
any of the department, commissions or agencies within the city government.
§ 6.05.   STREET. Includes the entire width between property lines of avenues
or highways.
§ 6.06.   STREET TREE. Includes any tree planted between the property lines of
streets or highways.
§ 7.00 TREES INTERFERING WITH UTILITIES.
   When it is determined by the Street Superintendent that the planting of any
trees in a certain area of the city would, in fact, interfere with the
operation of any utilities within the city, this will be sufficient reason not
to issue a permit for the planting of said trees. This provision applies both
to easements presently in existence and any future easements dedicated for such
purposes.
§ 8.00 NOTICE TO REMOVE TREES.
   If the Street Superintendent of the city, upon examination and inspection in
person or by some qualified person acting for him or her, shall determine, with
reasonable certainty, that violation of this chapter exists, he or she shall
immediately serve, or cause to be served, upon the owner, occupant or person in
charge of such property a written notice to remove, trim or prune the offending
tree or trees, including that such must be done within ten days of service of
said notice; and if such owner, occupant or person in charge of said property
failed to comply with said notice within ten days of receipt thereof, the
Council, upon notice and hearing, may cause the same to be removed, trimmed or
pruned and the cost thereof assessed against the property.
CHAPTER 5: REQUIREMENTS FOR INSTALLATION OF PUBLIC UTILITIES AND MINIMUM
STANDARDS FOR USE
Section
   
1.00   Applicability
   
2.00   Construction permits
   
2.01   Bond
   
2.02   Certificate of insurance
   
2.03   Construction permit fee
   
2.04   Primary electric system
   
3.00   Plans and specifications
   
4.00   As-built plans
   
5.00   Suspension of contractor and subcontractor licenses
   
5.01   Informal notice
   
5.02   Written notice
   
5.03   Second notice
   
5.04   Suspension
   
5.05   Reinstatement
   
6.00   Underground electric systems
   
6.01   Casings
   
6.02   Locating wire
   
6.03   Red warning tape
   
6.04   Installation below grade level
   
6.05   Switch gear
   
6.06   YRD line markings
   
7.00   Gas main and services
   
8.00   Work performed by the city
§ 1.00 APPLICABILITY.
   Save where otherwise specifically stated, the terms of this chapter shall be
applicable to all public utility companies, contractors, subcontractors,
subdividers and all persons and firms engaged in the installation, construction
or reconstruction of public utility improvements within the city.
§ 2.00 CONSTRUCTION PERMITS.
   A construction permit shall be required before the work is commenced.
Application therefor shall be made to the City Public Works Department. The
application shall be accompanied by a license permit bond, a certificate of
insurance and the permit fee. The Public Works Department shall issue the
permit or reject the application in writing within ten days of the date of
application.
§ 2.01 BOND.
   The license permit bond shall be in the amount of $10,000 or 5% of the
contract price, whichever is higher.
§ 2.02 CERTIFICATE OF INSURANCE.
   (A)   The certificate of insurance shall show liability limits of no less
than the following:
 
Bodily injury     $300,000 per person
                  $500,000 per accident
Property damage   $300,000 per person
                  $300,000 per accident
General liability $500,000
 
   (B)   The city shall be named as an insured. The Street Superintendent may,
in his or her discretion, require or accept an agreement to indemnify and hold
harmless the city.
§ 2.03 CONSTRUCTION PERMIT FEE.
   (A)   Construction permit fees are as follows:
 
Total Valuation  Fee
$1 to $50,000    $50
50,000 and above $50 for the first $50,000 of valuation and $1 for each
                 additional $1,000 of valuation or fraction thereof
 
   (B)   The fee shall be submitted with the application for a construction
permit and will cover work by the Street Superintendent and City Inspector.
§ 2.04 PRIMARY ELECTRIC SYSTEM.
   No primary electric systems shall be installed within the street right-of-
way, unless permission has been expressly granted by the Public Works
Department and the Electric and Water Utility Board.
§ 3.00 PLANS AND SPECIFICATIONS.
   (A)   At least ten days prior to the time of application for construction
permit, unless it is an emergency or minor repairs, two sets of plans and
specifications shall be filed with the Public Works Department. The Public
Works Department shall review the same and make corrections or revisions as to
location and conflicts with other utilities that are deemed necessary. Permits
are not required for services but if a conflict is apparent, it shall be
reviewed by the Public Works Department. Applications are available at the City
Clerk’s office.
   (B)   One set of plans and specifications, showing any corrections or
revisions required by the Public Works Department, will be returned with the
construction permits. The ten days required to file for construction permit may
be reduced to three days where no major conflicts occur.
   (C)   Location of utilities within easements or rights-of-way shall be
subject to the approval of the Public Works Department in order to minimize all
conflicts. All plans and specifications shall comply with the State Electric
Safety Code; N.E.C. Code; all local, state and federal codes; and regulations
as now adopted or adopted in the future. No primary electric systems shall be
installed within the street right-of-way, unless prior approval has been
granted by the Public Works Department and the City Utility Board.
§ 4.00 AS-BUILT PLANS.
   Within 30 days after completion of the work, the permit holder shall file
with the Public Works Department two sets of as-built plans. As-built plans
shall show all easements, public or private, and the exact location within the
easement of the improvement, including distance from the property line and
depth. Conflicts with all other utilities must be clearly shown. Failure to
file the required as-built plans shall be grounds for suspension of a
contractor’s license as set forth below.
§ 5.00 SUSPENSION OF CONTRACTOR AND SUBCONTRACTOR LICENSES.
   Contractors and subcontractors, including those installing, constructing or
reconstructing public improvements within the city, are licensed by the city
and must perform satisfactorily as a condition of the license. The City
Administrator, City Engineer, Building Inspector and Street Superintendent
shall follow the procedure set forth below when a question of licensee
performance arises.
§ 5.01 INFORMAL NOTICE.
   The licensee shall be given notice verbally or by means of informal notes
regarding conditions where workmanship should be improved, work items need to
be completed or situations must be corrected. No records of the informal notice
need be kept.
§ 5.02 WRITTEN NOTICE.
   When a licensee fails to respond to the informal notice, a written notice
shall be given. This written notice shall be dated and shall call attention to
specific items of concern. The notice shall be either hand delivered to the
licensee or mailed to the licensee at its address as shown on its license. The
procedure set forth in this chapter shall be clearly printed on the back of
such notice.
§ 5.03 SECOND NOTICE.
   The second notice shall relate to the same or similar items noted in the
written notice set forth in Step Two. It shall be in writing and hand delivered
or mailed as set forth in Step Two. This notice shall contain the following
information: “This is a Second Notice. It is active for thirty days. No permits
will be issued to you during this time unless the items below have been
corrected. If the items are not corrected within thirty days, your license to
work in Eldridge will be suspended.”
§ 5.04 SUSPENSION.
   Suspension shall be automatic if the 30-day period set forth in Step Three
expires without the correction of the items or without further agreement
between the city and the licensee. Notice of the suspension shall be in writing
and shall be either personally delivered to the licensee or mailed to the
licensee at its address as shown on the license. If this suspension is not
appealed to the City Council within 15 days of the suspension notice, the
license will be revoked. A licensee may appeal to the City Council at any step,
but, in any event, no later than 15 days after the date of the suspension
notice. The City Council may sustain the action of the city’s staff or may
excuse the notice either with or without conditions.
§ 5.05 REINSTATEMENT.
   A license which has been revoked will be reinstated only by the City Council
and only after the licensee in question has personally appeared before the
Council.
§ 6.00 UNDERGROUND ELECTRIC SYSTEMS.
§ 6.01 CASINGS.
   Rigid ferrous metal casing or conduit shall be used in all areas where
electric URD systems are located under or cross under public streets, private
streets, alleys, railroads, public ways and the like and shall further be used
where electric URD systems are laid over or under water mains, sewer mains or
other utility services, all subject to the review of the Public Works
Department and the City Utility Board.
§ 6.02 LOCATING WIRE.
   A locating wire of the type T.W. #12, solid copper, minimum shall be
installed 12 to 18 inches below ground level, except where concentric wire is
installed and only on primary routes.
§ 6.03 RED WARNING TAPE.
   A red warning tape, four inches wide, shall be installed 12 to 18 inches
below the ground level only on primary and secondary.
§ 6.04 INSTALLATION BELOW GRADE LEVEL.
   All primary URD electrical systems shall be installed 42 inches below grade
level. Secondary services shall be installed a minimum of 36 inches below grade
level.
§ 6.05 SWITCH GEAR.
   All transformer, primary switch gear and secondary switch gear shall be of
the above ground type and shall be installed with tags and a sign with the
following language: “Danger High Voltage”.
§ 6.06 YARD LINE MARKINGS.
   (A)   All primary and secondary URD lines, exclusive of service wires, shall
be marked with a sign at least 12 inches by 18 inches in size and worded as
follows:
   “Before digging or driving post call or contact                            .
Telephone during working hours                            ,/after
hours                               . Company
name                                         .”
   (B)   Such signs shall be of metal, with black lettering on a yellow
background and shall be affixed to a post which is a minimum of 48 inches long.
The sign shall be at least 32 inches above the ground level after installation
and shall not be further than 250 feet apart.
   (C)   Adhesive signs shall be affixed to all secondary pedestals, all
transformers, switch gears and the like located at ground level stating “Danger
High Voltage”. Letters should be red on white background.
§ 7.00 GAS MAIN AND SERVICES.
   Gas mains and services installed in the city shall be of the ferrous metal
type or plastic type approved for that use. If plastic gas mains and services
are installed, the following shall be required.
§ 7.01.   A locating wire of the type T.W. #12 minimum, solid copper, shall be
installed in the same trench as the main or service near the bottom.
§ 7.02.   A yellow warning tape, four inches wide, shall be installed 12 to 16
inches below finished grade level.
§ 7.03.   Plastic gas mains shall be installed within rigid metal conduit, or
other casing as may be required by the City Public Works Department, when the
gas main is located under or crosses under any public street, private street,
alley, railroad and the like and where the main crosses over or under any water
main, sewer main, underground electric utility or other public utility. Conduit
shall be right-of-way to right-of-way when possible.
§ 7.04.   Plastic gas mains shall meet ASTM Standard D-2513, or as may be
required or approved under the auspices of the State Commerce Commission, and
all other local, state or federal codes and regulations.
§ 8.00 WORK PERFORMED BY THE CITY.
   Whenever employees of the city are required to supplement or repair any part
of construction performed under this chapter or repair any damage to city
utilities or streets resulting from work performed under this chapter, the city
shall be entitled to reimbursement at the rate of $14 per work-hour. The
charges shall be assessed against the holder of the construction permit. If the
charges so assessed are not paid, further construction permits will not be
issued to that person or firm, and the license permit bond shall be used to
satisfy the charges.
CHAPTER 6: RECOVERING COSTS ON SEWER AND WATER SERVICES
Section
   
1.00   Scope
   
2.00   Construction costs
   
3.00   Recompense
   
4.00   Project enactment
   
5.00   Standards
§ 1.00 SCOPE.
   This chapter applies to water and sewer lines installed to bridge land which
has not yet been subdivided. With the approval of the Utility Board of Trustees
(water) or the City Council (sewer), developers may install such services and
be recompensed for same under the terms set forth below.
§ 2.00 CONSTRUCTION COSTS.
   The developers shall provide documentation of the estimated and actual costs
of said construction.
§ 3.00 RECOMPENSE.
   The Utility Board of the City Council shall establish reasonable connection
charges designed approximately to cover the actual costs of construction.
Connection charges for water mains shall be on a front foot served basis;
connection charges for sewers shall be on an area served basis with the
influence area clearly defined. For a period of up to ten years following the
acceptance of the construction, 75% of said connection charges collected shall
be paid to the developers, their heirs or assigns.
§ 4.00 PROJECT ENACTMENT.
   The Utility Board or the City Council shall establish the specific terms for
any project of this type by resolution. Such resolution shall have the force of
contract on both the developers involved and the city.
§ 5.00 STANDARDS.
   The same standards shall apply as apply in subdivisions.

§ 1.00 TITLE AND ADOPTION.
   (A)   The City Council does ordain as follows: that specific technical codes
listed for adoption in this chapter, two copies of each, which are on file in
the office of the City Clerk, being marked and designated collectively as: “the
City of Eldridge Building Code”, for the city, be and are hereby adopted in
full, excluding their appendices (except as may herein be amended, modified,
revised, changed or deleted) and further being placed in
Title C: Public Works,
Chapter Eight: Adoption of Specific Codes. This adoption repeals and supersedes
all previous codes and ordinances or parts of codes and ordinances in conflict
herewith, and provides for an effective date. If any conflict exists between
requirements in the specific technical codes, state codes or municipal codes
adopted, the municipal code requirement shall apply.
   (B)   The City Clerk shall certify the adoption of these specific technical
codes and this chapter and shall cause the same to be published as required by
law. These specific technical codes and this chapter shall take effect and be
in force, from and after its approval and publishing as required by law, with
an enforcement date of January 1, 2025.
   (C)   All buildings shall be required to comply with the code in force at
the time the building permit was issued, and the city retains the right to
prosecute owners of buildings for code violations under those codes, even if
the codes are amended or replaced by newer versions.
   (D)   Remodeling or reconstruction of buildings shall comply with the codes
as prescribed therein.
(Ord. 2024-14, passed 11-18-2024)
§ 2.00 SCOPE AND PURPOSE.
   (A)   These specific technical codes and this chapter establish the minimum
regulations governing the conditions and maintenance of all properties,
buildings and structures, as regulated herein, by providing the standards for
supplied utilities and facilities and other physical things and conditions
essential to ensure that structures are safe, sanitary and fit for occupancy
and use and includes provisions for the condemnation of buildings and
structures which are unfit for human occupancy and use, including the
demolition of structures.
   (B)   These specific technical codes and this chapter also include
regulations for controlling the development, enlargement, conversion,
occupancy, use, height, area, design, construction, quality of materials,
erection, installation, alteration, repair, location, relocation, replacement,
addition to and maintenance of, the building envelope, all plumbing, mechanical
and electrical systems, including the safeguarding of life and property from
fire and explosion hazards arising from the storage, handling and use of
hazardous substances, materials and devices, and from conditions hazardous to
life or property in the occupancy of buildings and premises and providing for
the issuance of permits, collection of associated fees, authority to inspect
and apply the provisions as herein set forth, within the jurisdiction of the
city.
   (C)   All of the provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of these
specific technical codes and those existing in this chapter are hereby referred
to, adopted and made part hereof, as if fully set out in this chapter, with the
revisions, additions, insertions, deletions and changes as herein prescribed in
this chapter.
   (D)   If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of these
specific technical codes and/or this chapter is for any reason held to be
unconstitutional, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining
portions of these specific technical codes and/or ordinance. The city hereby
declares that it would have approved these specific technical codes and this
chapter, and each section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrases thereof,
irrespective of any findings that any one or more sections, subsections,
sentences, clauses or phrases be asserted to be potentially, or found and
declared to be unconstitutional.
   (E)   Nothing in this chapter or the specific technical codes hereby adopted
shall be construed to affect any suit or proceeding impending in any court, or
any rights acquired, or liability incurred, or any cause or causes of action
acquired or existing under any act, code or ordinance hereby repealed, as cited
in this chapter; nor shall any just or legal right or remedy of any character
be lost, impaired or affected by this chapter.
   (F)   The city’s building code has been adopted and is used in conjunction
with all other codes and ordinances adopted by the city, including, but not
limited to, the applicable provisions of the State Building Code, the County
Board of Health, the State Department of Natural Recourses and the State Fire
Marshal’s office. Compliance with each of these regulations and those of other
agencies shall be required.
   (G)   The provisions contained herein shall not be construed to include all
of the regulations pertaining to buildings and developments. The city’s
building code shall be applied to all of the aforementioned specific technical
codes and ordinances and nothing contained herein shall be interpreted as
prohibiting or limiting enforcement by the building official or other
authorized personnel of the city or any other authorized agencies, in the
performance of their duties.
§ 3.00 ADMINISTRATION/POWERS AND DUTIES OF THE BUILDING OFFICIAL.
   (A)   Administration and enforcement of these specific technical codes and
ordinances pertaining hereto is a function of the building inspection division
of the city. Whenever the term or title administrative authority, authority
having jurisdiction, authorized representative, building inspector, building
official, code enforcement officer, code official, Fire Chief, inspector or
similar designation is used herein, or in any of the specific technical codes,
such term or title shall be construed to mean the Building Official, designated
by special appointment by the Mayor with the approval of the City Council.
   (B)   In accordance with prescribed procedures and with the approval of the
appointing authority, the Building Official may appoint related technical
officers, inspectors and other employees as shall be authorized from time to
time. He or she may deputize such inspectors or employees as may be necessary
to carry out code related duties.
   (C)   The Building Official (or other related technical officers, inspectors
and designees, as may be appointed) shall, upon proper inspection request and
notification from the permit holder, perform such specified inspections as
indicated by the respective codes and this chapter. Such work shall be made
ready and complete and shall stand and pass any tests as prescribed by the
respective codes. Upon such inspection, if the work being inspected conforms to
the requirements for such installation, the Building Official shall approve
that portion of work. If such work is found to be incomplete, or fails any
prescribed tests or is not in conformance with code provisions pertaining to
such work, the Building Official may provide verbal or written notice of the
necessary corrections. Such work shall be made to comply as required and may be
subject to a re-inspection (with re-inspection fees as may be warranted) upon
completion of such necessary corrections.
   (D)   The Building Official shall also provide business license inspections
for the issuance of a certificate of occupancy and the business license for
those new and existing properties where the proposed business is to be located.
This inspection is intended verify the present conditions of the buildings or
structures, which the new business is utilizing, are in conformance with
specific code provisions pertinent to the use and occupancy of the proposed new
business. If code violations are identified, a correction notice (verbal or
written) shall be issued, indicating the violations and such violations shall
be corrected prior to a certificate of occupancy and or business license being
issued. When no change in occupancy or use is encountered, such inspection need
not be performed unless there is reason to believe a violation exists.
§ 3.01 CONTRACTORS LICENSE/PERMIT BOND AND CERTIFICATE OF INSURANCE.
   All persons, firms or corporations desiring to engage in a contracting for
hire or the implementation of any works regulated by the specific technical
codes within the city must comply with the licensing, bonding and insurance
requirements contained in
Title A, Chapter 18.
§ 4.00 SPECIFIC TECHNICAL CODES ADOPTED.
§ 4.01.   The following codes are hereby adopted in full except for such
portions as may hereinafter be deleted, modified or amended and all subsequent
supplements to the below mentioned international codes as published.
   (A)   2021 International Building Code;
   (B)   2021 International Residential Code;
   (C)   2015 International Property Maintenance Code;
   (D)   Uniform Plumbing Code, as adopted by the State of Iowa;
   (E)   2020 National Electric Code;
   (F)   International Mechanical Code, as adopted by the State of Iowa;
   (G)   2015 International Energy Conservation Code;
   (H)   2015 International Existing Building Code;
   (I)   2021 Swimming Pool and Spa Code; and
   (J)   2021 International Fire Code.
(Ord. 2024-14, passed 11-18-2024)
§ 4.02.   An official copy of the above codes are on file in the office of the
City Clerk for inspection.
§ 4.03.   To establish flood hazard areas, the City Council has adopted a flood
hazard map and supporting data. This flood hazard map includes areas of special
flood hazards as identified by the Federal Emergency Management Agency on FIRM
Map #190574 for the city, dated September 1, 1991. The adopted flood hazard map
and supporting data are hereby set forth in
Title D, Chapter 3.
§ 4.04.   If any conflict exists between the adopted international codes,
uniform codes and other city ordinances, the more restrictive code requirement
applies.
§ 4.05.   This code adoption shall take effect on January 1, 2025. The city
retains the right to prosecute code violations under previous codes. Remodeling
or reconstruction of buildings shall comply with the codes as prescribed
therein.
(Ord. 2024-14, passed 11-18-2024)
§ 5.00 AMENDMENTS TO THE 2021 INTERNATIONAL BUILDING CODE.
§ 5.01.   The International Building Code, 2021 edition, published by the
International Code Council, 4051 West Flossmoor Road, Country Club Hills, IL
60478, is hereby adopted as the requirements for the design, construction,
alteration, relocation, demolition, installation, use and occupancy of every
building structure or appurtenances attached to such structures with the
following amendments.
   (A)   101.2 Title. Insert “City of Eldridge, Iowa” as [NAME OF
JURISDICTION].
   (B)   101.4.2 Mechanical. Replace “International Mechanical Code” with “Iowa
Mechanical Code”.
   (C)   101.4.3 Plumbing. Replace “International Plumbing Code” with “Iowa
Plumbing Code”.
   (D)   103.1 Creation of Enforcement Agency. Insert “Building Safety
Department” in place of “insert name of department”.
   (E)   105.2 Building. Delete “(2) Fences” in its entirety.
   (F)   105.2 Building. Delete “(6) Sidewalks and driveways” in its entirety
and replace with the following: “(6) Concrete flatwork on private property”.
   (G)   105.3.2 Time limitation of Application. Change “180 days” and “90
days” to “30 days”.
   (H)   105.5 Expiration. Delete and replace with “105.5 Expiration. Every
permit issued under the provisions of this Code shall expire twelve (12) months
from the date of issue. Exception: a permit application that is accompanied by
construction schedule of a longer specific duration may be issued for the term
of the construction schedule with approval of the Building Official. If the
work has not been completed by the expiration date of the permit, no further
work shall be done until the permit has been renewed by the owner or owners
agent and by payment of the renewal fee as established by Resolution of the
City Council, and provided no changes have been made in plans or location”.
   (I)   Chapter 11 Accessibility. Add “Where the provisions of this code
conflict with the Iowa State Building Code, Division VII, Accessibility Rules
and Regulations for the Physically Handicapped Section 661-16.700 (103A), the
latter shall apply”.
   (J)   Chapter 29 Plumbing Systems. Delete all references to the
“International Plumbing Code” and replace with “Iowa State Plumbing Code”.
   (K)   3303 Demolition. Add “3303.8 Site clearing. The demolition site shall
be cleared of all debris associated with the structures being removed. All
mechanical groundwork shall be removed from the site of demolition. Foundation
walls may be used as solid fill provided a site plan providing notice of the
location and depth of the foundation is recorded on the parcel with the Scott
County Recorder, and a recorded copy is filed with the Eldridge Building Safety
Department. In all cases, concrete shall be removed or collapsed so as to allow
burial 24” below final grade. Basement and on grade concrete slabs shall be
removed or substantially pulverized to allow adequate drainage. Demolition work
shall include site work as necessary to fill all excavations and to create a
smooth and even finish grade capable of supporting vegetation.
      Materials and specifications for filling and final site work are as
follows: Only material that will not decompose in the ground shall be used for
filling all excavations to within 24” of the top of the surrounding grade. The
top 24” of fill material shall be tillable soil, of which the formed aggregate
does not exceed 1-1/2 inches. An earthen crown shall be provided at the center
of the demolition site to allow for proper site drainage. Final site work shall
include stabilization with a vegetative cover of at least 70% over the entire
site.”
(Ord. 2024-14, passed 11-18-2024)

      1.   Foundations may support a roof in addition to the stipulated number
of floors. Foundations supporting roofs only shall be as required for
supporting one floor. Footings shall be continuous and contain a minimum of two
½-inch reinforcement bars, and have a minimum compressive strength of 2,500
pounds per square inch at 28 days.
         A one-story wood frame building used as a private garage detached,
accessory to a single family dwelling and not over 720 square feet in floor
area may be constructed on a floating slab-on-grade provided the following
conditions are met: A concrete perimeter grade-beam, twelve inches deep and
twelve inches wide and reinforced with two ½-inch reinforcement bars shall be
installed to support the exterior walls. A minimum four-inch thick concrete
floor slab reinforced with wire mesh or fiber mesh shall be installed within
the perimeter beam and shall be formed to allow a continuous pour consisting of
the required grade beam and floor.
      2.   Cast-in-place concrete foundation walls shall be concrete having a
minimum compressive strength of 28 days of not less than 3,000 pounds per
square inch. In addition, the following shall apply:
         A.   The minimum thickness of a wall shall be 7 ½ inches.
         B.   Walls shall be reinforced with no less than three half-inch
diameter, deformed ASTM A615 grade 40 steel bars placed horizontally at the
center of the wall, with one bar located near the top, one bar located near the
bottom and one bar located near mid-height of the wall.
   (Q)   R403.1.1 Minimum Size (Footings). Add “Exception 1. Deck footings not
supporting a roof or overhead structure may be a minimum 12 inches in diameter
and 42 inches below finished grade. Exception 2. All covered decks, screened
porches, three season rooms, four season rooms, room additions and similar
structures shall be supported on foundations compliant with Table R403.1 or
conforming to one of the following methods:
      (1)   Pier footings designed and stamped by a design professional.
      (2)   12 inch wide reinforced trench footing 42 inches in depth.
      (3)   16” wide spread footings 42 inches in depth with a minimum 8 inch
masonry or concrete foundation wall as per Figure 403.1.1”.
   (R)   R403.1.4.1 Frost Protection Exception 1, delete “600” and replace with
“720”. After “(3048 mm) or less” add: “, and where wall lengths do not exceed
30’ long.”
   (S)   R507.3.1 Delete table in its entirety and replace with “507.3.1 Deck
and Addition Footing Requirements.”
      “All decks and additions (screened porches, 3 seasons rooms, 4 seasons
rooms, etc.) with roof and flood loads combined shall have one of the
following:
      1.   Pier footings designed by a professional engineer.
      2.   12” wide trench footing 42” in depth extended out 12” past point
load.

concrete foundation wall.”

§ 7.00 AMENDMENTS TO THE 2015 INTERNATIONAL PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE.
§ 7.01.   The International Property Maintenance Code, 2015 edition, published
by the International Code Council, 4051 West Flossmoor Road, Country Club
Hills, IL 60478, are hereby adopted as the minimum requirements for the
condition of properties and existing structures with regard to the use,
occupancy and condition with the following amendments:
   (A)   101.1 Title. Delete the section and replace with “101.1 Title. These
regulations shall be known as the Eldridge Housing Code which includes the 2015
International Property Maintenance Code with amendments, hereinafter referred
to as “this code”.
   (B)   102.3 Application of other codes. Delete the section and replace with
“102.3 Application of other codes. Repairs, additions or alterations to a
structure, or changes of occupancy, shall be done in accordance with the
procedures and provisions of the Eldridge Municipal Code, which includes, but
is not limited to the Building Code, Fire Code, Fuel Gas Code, Mechanical Code,
Residential Code, Plumbing Code, and the Electrical Code. Nothing in this code
shall be construed to cancel, modify, or set aside provisions of the Zoning
Code adopted by the City Council of Eldridge, Iowa”.
   (C)   103.1 General. For purposes of this code, the Department of Property
Maintenance Inspection shall be the Eldridge Department of Building Safety and
the Code Official shall mean the Eldridge Building Official.
   (D)   103.5 Fees. Insert the City of Eldridge Fee Schedule.
   (E)   106.3 Prosecution of violation. Add to last sentence “or may be filed
as a special assessment with the Scott County Assessor’s Office”.
   (F)   106.4 Violation penalties. Delete the section and replace with “106.4
Violation penalties. Any person who shall violate a provision of this code, or
fail to comply therewith, or with any of the requirements thereof, shall be
prosecuted within the limits provided by state or local laws. Nothing herein
will prevent prosecution of violations of laws in addition to this code.
Violations of this code shall be considered a municipal infraction and civil
offense punishable by a civil penalty of not more than seven hundred fifty
dollars for each violation or if the infraction is a repeat offense, a civil
penalty not to exceed one thousand dollars for each repeat offense. (Iowa Code
§ 364.22) Each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served
shall be deemed a separate offense. Continued violations of this code for non-
compliance may result in suspension or revocation of a City of Eldridge issued
Rental Property Permit and occupants may be required to vacate the property.
Nothing contained herein shall prevent the City from taking action as
prescribed in other portions of the Code of Ordinances, including City funded
corrections and cost reclamation through a special assessment”.
   (G)   107.2 Form. “Add: 7. Be effective notice to anyone having interest in
the property whether recorded or not at the time of giving such notice and
shall be effective against any subsequent owner of the premises as long as the
violation exists and there remains an official copy of the notice in a file
maintained by the code official.”
   (H)   108.1.5 Dangerous Structure or premises: Add:
      “12.   Any building, structure or portion thereof that upon the
determination of the Eldridge Chief of Police has been illegally used to
manufacture, grow or otherwise produce a “controlled substance” as defined in
Iowa Code Chapter 124 shall be considered unfit for human occupancy. This
determination shall be based on a preponderance of the evidence. Occupancy may
be approved by the Building Official upon evidence being provided by the person
(s) responsible for compliance under this code that contamination levels are
safe for human habitation. In the event of the manufacture of methamphetamines
is determined to have taken place within a structure or portion thereof,
testing and evidence shall be done through an entity actively engaged in the
business of providing this information within the State of Iowa and shall be
completed under the supervision of an Industrial Hygienist.
      13.   Any residential structure that, due to an accumulation of objects,
goods, materials or substances inside, has inadequate light, ventilation,
livable space, unsanitary condition or lacks proper egress, or becomes an
unsafe fire threat due to an unusual amount of flammable or combustible
material that the building official declares the dwelling uninhabitable. (NOTE:
This situation may occur due to a “Hoarding Disorder” as listed in the
Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders. The City of Eldridge may
contact family members if a suspicion of hoarding is discovered.)”
   (I)   108.2 Closing of Vacant Structures. Add to the end of the last
sentence: “including a special assessment”.
   (J)   Add new section: “111.1.1 Waiver. Failure of any person to file an
appeal request in accordance with the provisions of this code shall constitute
a waiver of the right to a Board of Appeals hearing and adjudication of the
notice or order, or any portion thereof”.
   (K)   111.2 Membership of Board. Delete 111.2 through 11.2.5 in its entirety
and replace with: “111.2 Membership of Board. The Eldridge City Council shall
be the Board of Appeals”.
   (L)   111.3 Notice of Meeting. Change “20 days” to “30 days”.
   (M)   202 General Definitions. Add the following definitions:
      “201.1 CONDOMINIUM: A multi-family complex, dwelling, dwelling unit,
rooming unit, or sleeping unit which is recognized by the County Assessor’s
office as a Condominium (typically in compliance with Chapter 499B of the Code
of Iowa).
      201.2 COOPERATIVE. A multi-family complex, dwelling, dwelling unit,
rooming unit, or sleeping unit which is recognized by the County Assessor’s
office as a Cooperative (typically in compliance with Chapter 499A of the Code
of Iowa).
      201.3 OCCUPY. The living or sleeping in a premises regulated by this
Chapter, and shall not require that the person living or sleeping be included
in any rental agreement concerning the premises.
      201.4 PROPERTY MANAGER. See “Operator” section 202 of this code.
      201.5 RESIDENTIAL PROPERTY REGISTRATION. A registration with the City of
Eldridge of a rental property by the operator of every rental unit.
      201.6 RESIDENTIAL RENTAL PROPERTY; RESIDENTIAL RENTAL UNIT. A structure
containing one or more dwelling units, rooming units, or sleeping units which
is not eligible for the Iowa Homestead Credit for tax purposes; also any
structure or part of a structure used as a home, residence, or sleeping unit by
a single person, household unit, or any person other than the legal owner of
the property, which is let, leased or rented from or otherwise occupied by
permission of the owner or other person in control of such unit, whether by
day, week, month, year or any other term, regardless of monetary exchange. The
term Rental Unit or Residential Rental Unit may refer to a unit within a
residential rental property, a single family dwelling, dwelling unit, rooming
house, rooming unit or premises as the context requires.
      Exceptions:
      a.   Hotels and Bed and Breakfast Inns as defined by Iowa Code Chapter
137.
      b.   All facilities that are licensed or certified by the Iowa Department
of Inspections and Appeals.
      c.   Condominiums subject to private association agreements prohibiting
use as a rental property.
      d.   An owner occupied dwelling unit where all occupants live as one
family unit, regardless of familial relationship. Interior door locks are of
the non-key type and the kitchen, halls, storage and utility spaces are not
segregated for separate use between occupants.
      201.7 RENTAL PERMIT. A certificate obtained by an owner or operator from
the City of Eldridge authorizing the use of a property as a rental property by
providing a registration application and vouching for the compliance with the
applicable provisions of this chapter. Permits not renewed shall expire after
24 months following its date of issuance, unless sooner suspended or revoked as
hereinafter provided”.
   (N)   302.1 Sanitation. Delete and replace with “302.1 Sanitation. All
exterior property and premises shall be maintained in a clean, safe and
sanitary condition. The occupant shall keep in a clean and sanitary condition
that part of the exterior property which such occupant occupies or controls.
This provision shall not relieve the owner of responsibility under 301.2. No
exterior accumulation of garbage, refuse, rubbish, household goods, materials
or equipment including but not limited to appliances and furnishings
